*Extracted on: 20230902*

## Game Development Process
- **Current Focus:** Primarily on integrating and refining new 3D models and textures provided by collaborator Biobank. This includes models for game objects (switches, blocks), enemies (Goomba, fish), and environmental effects (fire, stars).
- **Level Development:** Actively working on specific levels, such as "Bozo's office."
- **Technical Refinement:** Ongoing work to fix N64-specific issues like floating point exceptions and addressing bugs related to the Fast64 toolchain.
- **Performance Optimization:** Conscious of performance implications of new assets, such as texture memory (e.g., fish model discussion) and render times, though sometimes prioritizes visual fidelity or development speed over micro-optimizations (e.g., "Two triangles don't matter," using separate models for cap switch states instead of bones).
- **Iterative Cycle:** The stream showcases a cycle of model import, in-game testing, identifying issues (visual glitches, incorrect behavior, crashes), debugging, and making iterative adjustments based on Kaze's judgment and collaborator feedback.
- **Tooling Challenges:** Kaze expresses frustration with limitations or bugs in the development tools (Fast64, lack of automatic render area calculation) and N64 hardware, often requiring workarounds.
- **Asset Overhaul:** A significant portion of development involves replacing or heavily modifying vanilla Mario 64 assets with custom, higher-quality versions.

## Personal Insights
- **Strong Aesthetic Opinions:** Kaze has clear preferences for visual style and quality, often criticizing original Mario 64 assets ("vanilla blue switch... looks like dog shit") and striving for specific looks (e.g., smoother edges on textures, better lighting).
- **Pragmatism in Development:** While aiming for high quality, Kaze sometimes makes pragmatic choices to save development time or avoid overly complex solutions, especially if the tools are cumbersome (e.g., his stance on "switch bones" vs. multiple models for cap switches: "You're wasting minutes of my life having me implement a switch bone when they basically don't really work at all").
- **Problem-Solving Approach:** Demonstrates a persistent, hands-on approach to debugging and finding solutions to technical and visual issues, often thinking aloud and trying different methods.
- **Humor and Persona:** Maintains a humorous and sometimes irreverent persona during the stream (e.g., the "Mario 64, what is that?" running gag).
- **Reflection on Tools/Process:** Openly discusses frustrations with development tools and limitations, wishing for better features (e.g., "I've asked for a feature to manually and to automatically compute it [render area] so many times now").

## Collaborator Information
- **Badub (Composer):** No relevant information found in this transcript.
- **Biobak (Graphics Artist):**
    - **Primary Contributor:** The stream is heavily centered around integrating a large number of 3D models and textures created by Biobank ("today is probably going to be the bio backstream," "we are going to import all of Biobank's remade models today").
    - **Scope of Work:** Provides models for various game elements including switches (blue coin switch, cap switches), enemies (fish, Goomba), effects (ground pound stars, fire), and interactive blocks ("Net peanut"/sludge blarg boss).
    - **Interaction:** Kaze provides direct feedback to Biobank during the stream, discusses design choices, and makes technical adjustments to Biobank's assets for in-game implementation. Biobank also seems responsive, offering to update textures based on feedback (e.g., coin texture, button contrast).
    - **Creative Input:** Biobank proposes designs (e.g., switch designs, "Net peanut" concept) which Kaze then refines or implements. Kaze praises Biobank's ideas ("Biobank deserves a medal for that" regarding the sludge blarg's design).
- **Zeina (Animator):**
    - **Implied Contributions:** Kaze mentions handling Thwomp animations ("I'm just sending you Thwomp's animations right quick"). While not explicitly stated Zeina made them *in this transcript*, the prompt identifies her as the animator. This suggests Zeina provides animations that Kaze then integrates.
    - **Technical Animation:** For a new boss ("Net peanut"), Biobank suggests Kaze might be better suited for its "very technical animation," indicating a collaborative decision-making process on animation tasks.
- **Other Contributors:**
    - **Lila (Chat Contributor):** Actively provides real-time feedback on visuals, such as contrast on a button texture ("Lila is saying this needs more contrast") and design elements of an exclamation mark. Kaze acknowledges and sometimes acts on this feedback.
    - **XPM (Asset Contributor):** Mentioned as the creator of a cloud texture Kaze is still using ("Yes, I'm still using your cloud texture, I think, XPM. It has survived the test of time").

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
- **Visual Fidelity vs. Performance:** A recurring theme, e.g., choosing RGBA16 over CI4 for smoother texture edges despite larger size, or optimizing fish models to use fewer textures for batch rendering.
- **Lighting and Shading:** Extensive discussion on how to light models – baked lighting in textures vs. dynamic level lighting vs. vertex colors. Kaze generally prefers models to interact with world/level lighting ("it's usually better to have it work with world lights so that it actually looks like it's placed in the world"). This often involves complex combiner setups and texture adjustments.
- **Tool-Induced Challenges (Fast64):** Many problems are attributed to Fast64 bugs or limitations:
    - Armature import issues ("if you reimport the armature, Fuzz64 will fuck it up").
    - Texture loading order affecting performance if not handled correctly (Goomba feet texture).
    - Rendering inconsistencies between editor and game.
- **Floating Point Exceptions on N64:** Identified as an "annoying as fuck" issue to fix for several levels when running on actual N64 hardware.
- **Animation Design for Interactive Objects:**
    - **Cap Switches:** Kaze opts for using multiple distinct models for different states of cap switches rather than "switch bones" due to perceived unreliability and difficulty of the latter.
    - **Blue Coin Switch:** Decides against a complex animation due to its brief on-screen time (5 frames).
- **Gameplay Feel and Object Interaction:** Considers how objects behave and feel, e.g., the impact sound for a switch ("Okay, I want the stone sound"), how Mario interacts with new collision, and the visual feedback of a switch being pressed.
- **Reimagining Vanilla Elements:** Conscious decision to replace or significantly alter original SM64 models and behaviors Kaze deems subpar (e.g., "All the vanilla models are awful").

## Business Aspects
- **Content Creation Strategy:** Kaze mentions studying MrBeast's videos ("I actually study MrBeast's videos like a fucking nerd. I look at them and be like, Oh, why do people like this? How can I implement this?") This indicates a conscious effort to improve his streaming/YouTube content engagement, which is a form of marketing and audience building for his projects.
- **Monetization Stance:** Briefly touches on monetization when asked for a link to EverDrives: "I'm not going to advertise someone's products here for free... They need to pay me, I'm not posting it." This shows an awareness of his platform's value.
- **Donations:** Acknowledges a $5 donation, indicating community financial support via streaming.

## Key Quotes
- "I already said that today is probably going to be the bio backstream. Am I right about that? I guess you wanted to change so many models." (Highlights the collaborative nature and focus of the stream)
- "For the new sign video, I needed to record a lot of N64 footage. And unfortunately, I found out that a lot of the levels have floating point exceptions when you enter them right now on N64. Which is not going to be difficult to fix, but it's going to be annoying as fuck." (Illustrates a common development challenge and Kaze's attitude towards it)
- "All the vanilla models are awful. Damn. Give me one vanilla Mario 64 model that is not awful." (Showcases Kaze's strong opinions and the motivation behind the visual overhaul)
- "It never works for me [switch bones]. I don't know what you're doing differently. This is going to be our render area. You weren't kidding. This is a biomextreme today." (Emphasizes tool frustrations and his preferred workarounds, and again, the focus on Biobank's contributions)
- "I think that we can say that this is just a bug on the emulator plugin. Because I see no reason this wouldn't work... No, it renders like this even on NEMU. Something is definitely wrong in the combiner." (Demonstrates the debugging process and cross-referencing issues on different emulators/hardware)

## Potential Interview Topics
1.  **The Kaze-Biobank Collaboration Dynamic:** Explore the workflow, communication, and creative synergy between Kaze and Biobank in remaking the game's assets. How are disagreements resolved? How are ideas pitched and developed?
2.  **Navigating N64 Limitations and Tooling Challenges:** Delve deeper into the specific technical hurdles faced (Fast64 bugs, N64 hardware constraints) and the creative workarounds Kaze employs. What are the most frustrating limitations, and what are the most satisfying solutions he's found?
3.  **Kaze's Design Philosophy for "Return to Yoshi's Island":** Discuss his vision for the game, why he feels the need to overhaul SM64's original assets so thoroughly, and what he aims to achieve in terms of player experience and aesthetic.
4.  **The Role of Community and Live Streaming in Development:** How does live streaming the development process and interacting with the chat (e.g., feedback from Lila) influence the game's direction or specific design choices?
5.  **Evolution of the Project and Future Scope:** How has the project evolved since its inception? What are the remaining major tasks (e.g., "four and a half levels left," Bowser level, overworlds)? What is the ultimate goal for "Return to Yoshi's Island"?

*Extracted on: 20230909*

## Game Development Process
- The game is stated to be approximately 75% complete ("75 mean Quick 64. Yeah").
- Current focus includes integrating character assets (models, animations like Wiggler's) and programming their behavior.
- Development of specific levels and quests is ongoing, such as "Bowser's office," the "Union Mission" involving a strike and a "strike breaker" boss, and the "Wild West Valley" level.
- Work includes reworking existing levels for visual and performance improvements (e.g., the "biomech" level).
- Implementation of new game systems like an options menu and Yoshi Coins (replacing 100-coin stars) is in progress.
- A significant amount of dialogue is being written and implemented (169 dialogues mentioned, more than double SM64).

## Personal Insights
- Kaze expresses a long-standing enjoyment of core Mario mechanics ("Dude ever since I was little I loved stomping Koopas").
- He reflects on the potential negative impact of AI on human creativity and purpose ("It's like why even try if something better can be done without any effort?").
- He is pragmatic about the risks involved in ROM hacking, such as timing game releases to avoid Nintendo takedowns ("I like to release my games around September and Just because that's the time where it's like least likely Nintendo's gonna take them down").
- He shows a desire to create unique and atmospheric experiences, focusing on level design and narrative elements like the "Union Mission."
- Kaze is candid about the challenges of development, including debugging and working within technical limitations.

## Collaborator Information
- **Badub (Composer):**
    - Provided a new song for the second Bowser level.
    - The music is designed with dynamic layers ("disable two channels and you get an indoors version and you can enable another channel to get an outdoors version") for atmospheric effect.
- **Biobak (Graphics Artist/Designer):**
    - Contributes 3D models and level design ideas.
    - Kaze consults with Biobak on concepts like the "conspiracy theory Yoshi room" and the aesthetics of the "child's room" level.
    - Described as "not a programmer. He does some 3D modeling on the air."
- **Zeina (Animator):**
    - Provides character animations, specifically mentioned for Wiggler (e.g., walk, jump, angry poses, stomping off).
    - Kaze was in the process of importing and integrating Zena's new Wiggler animations during the stream.
- **Other Contributors:**
    - **Pileback:** Provided an "assessment" or suggestion for the "child's room model" area.
    - **Legwood:** Edits Kaze's YouTube Shorts.
    - **Chat members (general):** Kaze frequently interacts with chat, sometimes incorporating their suggestions or answering their questions related to game design. Lila is a frequently interacting chat member.

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
- **Level Reworks:** The "biomech" level was significantly changed to feel more "vast" and "near infinite" with an improved cloud ocean and lighting.
- **Camera System:** Dealing with camera issues in tight spaces (like the elevator) is a challenge. Planned solutions include sphere collision for the camera and potentially fixed camera angles in specific locations.
- **Hitbox Design:** Approximating complex character shapes (like Wiggler) with N64's limited cylindrical hitboxes requires creative solutions ("What if he's just two cylinders like this?").
- **Quest/Narrative Design:** The "Union Mission" features a multi-stage narrative where minions strike, Bowser sends a "strike breaker," the plaza becomes ominous, and a boss (oil monster) attacks Mario.
- **Debugging:** A significant portion of the stream shows Kaze actively debugging various issues, such as elevator mechanics, object positioning (Toxboxes), and texture/animation glitches (Wiggler's face with Fast64).
- **Wiggler's Interactive Dialogue:** Wiggler's dialogue will change based on which parts of the construction site Mario has interfered with, serving as a hint system.
- **Technical Limitations:** Constant need to work within the N64's constraints regarding performance, rendering, and object complexity.

## Business Aspects
- **Release Strategy:** Kaze prefers releasing games around September, believing it's a time when Nintendo is less likely to issue takedowns.
- **Monetization/Distribution:**
    - He will not sell physical cartridges due to legal risks ("if I do I will get sued to shit").
    - He might sell merchandise like game boxes and instruction booklets, which could include a QR code for downloading the ROM (not from him directly).
- **Marketing:**
    - Uses YouTube Shorts for promotion, paying an editor ($5 per short).
    - Analyzes the cost-effectiveness of Shorts, noting they are not consistently profitable but hopes for viral hits.
- **Personal Finances:** Mentions personal financial situation (low income affecting house loan eligibility) which could indirectly influence his work setup.

## Key Quotes
- "This game is Return to Yoshi's Island." (Confirmation of the game's title)
- "So, yeah, I was working on Bowser's office here... And when you go here the shy guy says, oh you're trying to visit Bowser go into the Waiting seats and wait forever... And then this will be the elevator." (Describing a new level and its mechanics)
- "Dude, this level [biomech rework] is starting to look pretty good... It like looks so much more vast It looks less like you're caged in an old thing." (On iterating and improving level design)
- "I'm not gonna make a physical cartridge because if I do I will get sued to shit. But I might make a box and an instruction booklet and all that and I'm probably gonna sell those as merch." (On release and monetization plans)

## Potential Interview Topics
- **The Creative Vision for "Return to Yoshi's Island":** Explore the core inspirations, desired player experience, and how this project differs from or builds upon his previous work.
- **Collaborative Dynamics in ROM Hacking:** Discuss the process of working with contributors like Badub, Biobak, and Zeina – how are tasks managed, creative visions aligned, and challenges overcome in a distributed, informal team?
- **Navigating the "Business" of Fan Games:** Delve into the strategies for releasing ROM hacks, managing legal risks, and attempts at monetization through merchandise or content creation around the game.

- **Kaze's Perspective on AI and the Future of Game Creation:** Expand on his expressed concerns about AI's impact on human creativity and discuss his outlook for the fan game community and his own role within it.

## Game Development Process
-   Currently focused on developing a specific boss for a level in "Return to Yoshi's Island," including its attack patterns, movement AI, and associated animations.
-   Integrating and troubleshooting code from collaborators, such as performance-enhancing code from Silas, which has led to debugging sessions (e.g., addressing a 30 FPS issue).
-   Actively working on creating and refining game assets, like boss animations, and addressing technical bugs related to them.
-   Kaze mentions working on a "Banjo hack," indicating that "Return to Yoshi's Island" is one of several projects he juggles, potentially impacting its development timeline.
-   Technical aspects like managing ROM space for assets (e.g., a large song file) and optimizing game performance (FPS) are ongoing concerns.

## Personal Insights
-   Kaze expresses strong opinions on technical subjects, such as his critique of the Quake inverse square root algorithm's specific optimizations.
-   He reflects deeply on the challenges of game design within the ROM hacking scene, particularly concerning player expectations for 100% completion. He feels this expectation can stifle design freedom for truly hidden or difficult optional content.
    -   "I actually had a pretty big revelation today. And that is, that there's a problem with playing ROM-Mix. And that is that the player's expectation is that they can easily 100% the game... And I think that really takes away a lot of design space."
-   Kaze has a defined philosophy on handling community feedback: he believes player feelings are valid and must be acknowledged, but their proposed reasons or solutions can often be misguided.
    -   "See, my philosophy is, what people feel, in a way, is real. You can't change that fact. But their reasoning is most of the time stupid."
-   He shows passion for creating a rich game world, emphasizing the importance of secrets in the overworld.
    -   "The overworld needs to be full of secrets. That is so important. That's gonna make or break the game. Guaranteed."

## Collaborator Information
-   **Badub (composer):** No relevant information found in this transcript segment.
-   **Biobak (graphics artist/idea contributor):**
    -   Actively participates in the stream chat, offering design suggestions.
    -   Kaze acknowledges a "very good idea by biomech" regarding "metal teeth" for the boss being worked on.
-   **Zeina (animations):**
    -   This transcript segment does not detail specific animation contributions from Zeina to "Return to Yoshi's Island." Kaze is shown working on implementing and debugging animations himself during the stream.
    -   Lila (Kaze's partner, who may be Zeina as per external context) is present and actively participates verbally in the stream, discussing various topics with Kaze and the chat, including the wedding gift they prepared.
-   **Other Contributors:**
    -   **Silas:** Provided code intended to improve game performance (e.g., address FPS drops). Kaze is shown integrating and debugging this code.
        -   "This is actually Silas' code He gave me a new version of this that is supposedly a lot faster But it does not seem to work."
    -   **Chat Participants (e.g., MarioBag, Clayman):** Provide real-time feedback, suggestions (like camera adjustments or ideas for game mechanics), and engage in discussions, influencing Kaze's thought process.

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
-   **Player Expectations vs. Design Freedom:** A major philosophical challenge is managing the common ROM hack player expectation of being able to 100% a game easily, which Kaze feels limits the ability to include very hard or obscure secrets. He ran a poll to gauge community sentiment on this.
-   **Performance Optimization:** Dealing with FPS drops (e.g., Mario's animations running at 30 FPS instead of 60) is a recurring technical challenge, sometimes linked to integrating external code.
-   **ROM Space Management:** A cool song idea for a "grand trial" is hampered by its large file size (5MB), highlighting the constraint of limited ROM space.
-   **Boss Design & Balancing:**
    -   Detailed work on a boss's attack patterns, movement, and visual cues (e.g., "oil" properties, appearance).
    -   Consideration of camera behavior during the boss fight to ensure good visibility for the player.
    -   Debating the penalty for failing in the boss arena (e.g., falling into oil), aiming for a balance that isn't overly frustrating. "I think water with damage over time is perfect."
-   **Difficulty Customization / Perk System:** Brainstorming a system of findable "perks" in the overworld (e.g., "no void outs," "higher spin jump") that players could equip one at a time. This is an attempt to offer difficulty modulation and cater to different playstyles without implementing a full RPG-like badge system.
    -   "If we have these badges just be findable in the overworld, and then you can just select one of them as like a special perk... I'm kind of fine with that."
-   **Overworld Design:** Strong emphasis on creating a "massive and intricate" overworld filled with secrets, considered crucial for the game's success.

## Business Aspects
-   **Community Engagement/Audience Research:** Kaze uses YouTube polls (e.g., on 100% completion expectations) to gather direct feedback from his audience, which can inform design decisions.
-   **Potential Collaboration/Outreach:** Kaze mentioned a discussion about potentially co-hosting or being a guest on a software engineering podcast with James Lambert, which could serve as a promotional or networking opportunity.
    -   "...the suggestion we had was that me and James Lambert on the podcast would, like, interview each other."
-   No direct mentions of funding, specific release dates, or distribution plans for "Return to Yoshi's Island" in this transcript segment.

## Key Quotes

We can't put hard challenges without people complaining. We can't put super secret hidden stuff without people complaining. And I think that really takes away a lot of design space."
-   "This is actually Silas' code He gave me a new version of this that is supposedly a lot faster But it does not seem to work... Okay, I'll let Celes [Silas] know."
-   "The overworld needs to be full of secrets. That is so important. That's gonna make or break the game. Guaranteed."

## Potential Interview Topics

How has this ongoing internal debate and community feedback (like the poll) shaped the design of secrets and difficulty in "Return to Yoshi's Island"?

*Extracted on: 20230930*

## Game Development Process
- **Overall Progress:** The game is stated to be "over 70% done" with "like four and a half courses" remaining to be completed.
- **Engine Enhancements:** Kaze has made significant improvements to his custom engine based on the Mario 64 decompilation. This includes reducing render time (e.g., a 5% improvement, saving 600 microseconds), making it easier to add shadows and culling radiuses to objects, and optimizing RAM usage.
- **Current Focus Areas (during the stream):**
    - Implementing a new, visually enhanced Star Select screen, including integrating assets from Biobak, programming animations, and resolving layout/centering issues.
    - Developing the "oil block" functionality and visuals.
    - Creating a robust player respawn system for when Mario falls into hazards, involving logic to find safe respawn points on level geometry.
- **Optimization:** A continuous effort, particularly in culling (fixing original SM64 culling logic to be more effective) and ensuring features run efficiently on N64 hardware (e.g., aiming for 60 FPS on the Star Select screen).
- **Iterative Development:** The stream shows a clear iterative process of coding, testing, debugging, and refining features (e.g., Star Select alignment, respawn behavior, camera adjustments).

## Personal Insights
- **Excitement about Technical Achievements:** Kaze expresses significant enthusiasm for performance gains: "this week was insane I found so many improvements literally I reduced render time by like 5% almost... 5% is so much I went from like 44 FPS to 46."
- **Frustration with External Factors:** He mentions frustration with YouTube channel logistics affecting video views: "I'm really sad that I fucked up today and I accidentally scheduled two videos on the shorts channel for today... and that's why it's getting less views than it should but yeah devastating."
- **Pragmatism and Tool Usage:** Kaze is open to using modern tools like ChatGPT for assistance with complex coding tasks: "Dude, it fucking works. That is so insane. You guys have no idea how hard that would have been to program by myself. And this is why I like chatgpd."
- **Strong Opinions on Development Practices:** He has firm views on certain development approaches, notably his preference for C++ over visual scripting tools like Blueprints for core programming: "fuck him honestly fuck him they have problem you know what pigs they like to roll around on dirt I'm not gonna stop them let them have fun let them roll around on dirt."
- **Sense of Humor and Candor:** Kaze often uses humor and speaks candidly about development struggles and successes.

## Collaborator Information
- **Badub:** Implied to be the composer. Kaze asks chat for "OST wishes for today," suggesting music selection is part of the stream or ongoing work. He also critiques a currently playing song ("this music fucking sucks dude").
- **Biobak (Graphics Artist):** A key collaborator providing visual assets.
    - Supplied new 3D models and designs for the Star Select screen (e.g., "bunny title.blend").
    - Kaze frequently refers to Biobak's intentions for the visuals and seeks clarification/feedback from him (or chat on his behalf) during the stream ("Is this screen the way we want the biobank?", "I think Biobank just wants it cut out, right?").
    - Communication seems to happen via Discord or similar platforms, with Kaze implementing Biobak's assets and vision.
- **Zeina (Animations):** Mentioned in a personal anecdote ("when Zeyna was over here I took her to see the seals"), but no specific contributions to the current development tasks in this stream are detailed.
- **Other Contributors:**
    - **Atlas:** Mentioned as the creator of star select screen assets, possibly using an array modifier in Blender ("Well atlas who's atlas it's an array modifier oh i see that works").
    - **Chat Members (e.g., Leela, Windows Empty, Platonically):** Actively provide feedback, suggestions, and engage in discussions, influencing Kaze's immediate troubleshooting and design thoughts.

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
- **Star Select Screen Redesign:**
    - **Goal:** Replace the "boring as shit" old star select with a more visually appealing and dynamic one, aiming for 60 FPS.
    - **Challenges:** Importing and scaling Blender models, aligning text and graphical elements, programming scrolling animations, ensuring correct rendering order, and fixing visual glitches (e.g., seams in scrolling background, pop-in).
    - **Solutions:** Decided to use one render function per selectable item for maximum flexibility instead of one geo layout. Extensive trial-and-error for positioning and animation.
- **Player Respawn System (Falling into Hazards):**
    - **Goal:** Create a fair and non-exploitable respawn mechanic where Mario fades out and reappears at a safe, recent location.
    - **Challenges:** Determining a "safe" respawn spot automatically, avoiding respawning inside geometry or on dangerous edges, handling camera transitions smoothly, and choosing appropriate death/respawn animations.
    - **Solutions:** Explored ideas like using the last non-object triangle Mario stood on. Used ChatGPT to generate code for calculating distance to triangle edges to validate respawn points. Iterated on camera behavior and Mario's animation state post-respawn.
- **Culling and Shadows:**
    - **Challenge:** Original SM64 culling was inefficient; adding shadows to enemies was difficult with Fast64.
    - **Solution:** Kaze fixed the culling logic for significant performance gains ("now everything that's off screen is actually getting culled"). His new engine simplifies adding shadows.
- **Camera Control Philosophy:**
    - **Decision:** Avoid explicit 8-direction camera snapping unless levels are designed for it (which they aren't in this game). Keep controls simple ("one button one output philosophy") to avoid making the game feel like a "tool."
- **Oil Block Visuals and Mechanics:** Mentioned as a task for the day, with initial thoughts on modeling a wave shape for the oil.
- **Decal System for Mario Effects:**
    - **Idea:** To add effects like oil stains, create a "decal Mario object" that renders over the normal Mario, allowing for transparency and fade effects.
    - **Consideration:** This is seen as a cool, performant way to add visual polish, but needs careful implementation if new Mario models are added later.

## Business Aspects
- **Patreon:** Mentioned as a way for supporters to identify themselves ("Let's say I'm a patron... you would have to tell me on patreon"). This implies Patreon is a source of community support/funding.
- **YouTube Channel Management:** Kaze discusses scheduling errors on his YouTube channels and the impact on video views, indicating an awareness of his online presence and audience engagement, which is relevant for marketing and visibility.
- **No explicit release/distribution plans discussed in detail**, other than the game being "in beta" and Kaze having access as a "beta tester" (referring to a tool or component, not necessarily the full game release status to public).

## Key Quotes
- "I made my engine a lot easier to use so now we can easily add shadows and culling radiuses to everything." (Highlights engine improvement and its impact)
- "we're missing like four and a half courses so we're like over 70% done at this point." (Provides a clear status update on game completion)
- "Basically, I fixed the culling so now everything that's off screen is actually getting culled and I put the culling into the object layout itself... and culling is correct and that saved like 600 microseconds... it's like a 3% improvement still that's insane." (Demonstrates technical problem-solving and impact)
- "Dude, it fucking works. That is so insane. You guys have no idea how hard that would have been to program by myself. And this is why I like chatgpd." (Shows candidness about challenges and embrace of modern tools)

## Potential Interview Topics
- **The Evolution of Kaze's Custom Engine:** How has the development of his engine for SM64 decompilation specifically benefited "Return to Yoshi's Island"? What were the biggest breakthroughs?
- **Collaboration Dynamics:** Explore the creative process with Biobak (and Atlas). How are visual concepts translated into the game? What is the feedback loop like?
- **Balancing Vision and N64 Constraints:** How does Kaze approach designing ambitious features (like the new Star Select or complex respawn logic) while respecting the N64's limitations?
- **Player Experience Philosophy:** Delve into Kaze's design principles for player controls, camera, and overall game feel, especially in the context of a ROM hack aiming for a polished experience.
- **The "Over 70% Done" Milestone:** What are the major remaining challenges or features to implement before "Return to Yoshi's Island" is considered complete? What are his feelings as he approaches the later stages of development?
- **Innovation in ROM Hacking:** How does Kaze see "Return to Yoshi's Island" pushing the boundaries of what's possible with SM64 ROM hacking, particularly with the aid of the decompilation project?

*Extracted on: 20231007*

## Game Development Process
-   Currently focused on developing the "Block Boss" fight for "Return to Yoshi's Island."
-   Significant progress on the boss fight mechanics was made off-stream, including performance improvements.
-   The stream covered work on the boss's fleeing animation, damage effects (color flashing, shaking, animation speed), and integrating a new song by Baduk.
-   Key tasks for the Block Boss include implementing its ability to disappear and reappear, defining player damage for failing certain mechanics, adding particles, and ensuring players take damage from an oil hazard.
-   The boss arena is undergoing a visual re-theme, moving from an oil barrel concept to a warehouse/cave hybrid.
-   ROM size is a critical concern, with music taking up a significant portion (approx. 35.6MB of a 64MB target). This necessitates exploring music compression or alternative audio formats.
-   The project is stated to have 11 out of 15 courses completed.
-   Kaze plans to finish the current Block Boss fight development off-stream.

## Personal Insights
-   Kaze prefers to work on more complex development tasks off-stream to maintain focus.
-   He expresses strong opinions on various topics, including philosophy (criticism of Emanuel Kant), social norms ("swears being a bad thing is such an American concept"), and game design principles (dislike of button prompts, games becoming "chores").
-   He values performance and engine-level understanding, discussing topics like C++ vs C, object struct memory management, and optimal coordinate systems (Z-Up for cache coherency).
-   Kaze acknowledges the difficulty of making good games: "It's more so than just it's hard to make a good game, and most people just don't."
-   He balances his passion project with external responsibilities: "I have a full-time job. I can't work on this unlimitedly."

## Collaborator Information
-   **Baduk (Composer):**
    -   Contributed a "really good" new song for the Boombox Koopas.
    -   Kaze mentions Baduk's music contributions in the context of overall sound design.
-   **Biobak (Graphics Artist - referred to as Biomech/Biobank in transcript):**
    -   Provided the 3D model for the Block Boss, which Kaze modified for damage visuals.
    -   Engaged in discussions about model issues (e.g., pivot points) and visual effects like N64 combiners.
    -   Kaze consulted Biomech for ideas on the boss arena's visual theming (e.g., cages).
-   **Zeina (Animations):**
    -   No direct mention of "Zeina" or specific animation contributions attributed to her by that name in this transcript. "Lila" (see Other Contributors) is a key technical collaborator whose work on Fast64 (the modeling/animation tool) may support the animation pipeline. Kaze discusses animation techniques like switch bones vs. animation bones, and issues with Fast64 affecting animation data.
-   **Other Contributors:**
    -   **Lila (Key Technical Collaborator):**
        -   Frequently addressed by Kaze regarding technical issues and bug fixes for "Fast64" (the SM64 modding toolset).
        -   Engaged in discussions about texture choices (e.g., tree stump texture) and low-level engine details (e.g., GeoASM node children).
        -   Her role appears crucial for maintaining/improving the development toolchain.
    -   **"the dupe" (Idea Contributor):**
        -   Suggested a music compression technique (streaming a repeating background beat separately).

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
-   **Block Boss Mechanics:**
    -   Designed to flee when Mario is on a "soap" platform, with speed increasing as it takes damage.
    -   Visual feedback for damage includes color flashing (orange), shaking, and faster animations.
    -   The fight involves multiple phases, requiring the player to use soap to attack, dodge waves, and manage platforming elements.
    -   A key challenge is clearly communicating attack mechanics to the player (Kaze believes the soap's purpose is obvious).
    -   The boss will have action states like disappearing and reappearing, and a punishment phase for player failure.
-   **Boss Arena Design:**
    -   The arena theme is being iteratively designed, moving from an "oil barrel" to a "junkyard," "oil tankers," "warehouse," and finally a "cave/warehouse mix" with a tilted square layout.
    -   The arena will feature dynamic elements like "grills" that move up and down.
    -   A challenge lies in integrating the soap spawning mechanism thematically (e.g., strike workers in jail cells, a janitor Koopa throwing soap).
-   **Technical Obstacles:**
    -   **ROM Size Limit (64MB):** Music is the largest consumer of space, prompting considerations for sequenced music, mono audio, or reducing streamed tracks.
    -   **Fast64 Tool Bugs:** Issues with the modding toolset (e.g., animation data corruption, node hierarchy problems) require workarounds or fixes.
    -   **Memory Management:** Kaze opts to reuse existing object variables (like `all_health`) to conserve RAM, rather than expanding object structures or implementing dynamic memory systems, due to performance concerns on N64.
-   **Balancing Difficulty:** Kaze aims to "not want the gap between like a bad player and a good player to be too big."

## Business Aspects
-   Kaze discusses a recent increase in his personal YouTube revenue, which he speculates might be due to YouTube's changes regarding ad-blockers. This income supports him but is not presented as direct funding for the game project itself.
-   He mentions purchasing a house and moving soon, a personal life event.
-   There is no explicit mention of marketing strategies, dedicated funding for "Return to Yoshi's Island," or specific release/distribution plans, beyond the typical understanding that ROM hacks are community-distributed. The project's release is contingent on Kaze's available time due to his full-time job.

## Key Quotes
-   "I've made a lot of progress on this fight off stream as usual... this might be something that I have to do to offstream because this is a bit too complicated for stream." (Highlights development workflow and complexity management).
-   "The problem is that most of it is music and we can't really compress that because it has to be streamed directly from ROM... two-thirds of the ROM is just music that we cannot compress." (Pinpoints a major technical constraint).
-   "This area is just not turning out as I want it to be." (Illustrates the iterative and sometimes frustrating nature of creative design, specifically for the boss arena).
-   "Video games are not supposed to be chores! That's my rant for the day." (Reflects Kaze's core game design philosophy).

## Potential Interview Topics
-   **The Creative Vision for the Block Boss:** Explore the inspirations and goals behind its unique mechanics (soap riding, fleeing behavior, multi-phase design) and the iterative process of bringing it to life.
-   **Navigating N64/SM64 Decompilation Limitations:** Delve into the specific challenges of working within the N64's constraints (ROM size, processing power, memory) and the SM64 decompilation, particularly regarding music, custom assets, and complex actor behavior.
-   **Collaboration in ROM Hacking:** Discuss the dynamic with collaborators like Baduk, Biomech, and Lila/Zeina. How are tasks divided? How is creative and technical feedback exchanged and integrated, especially in a remote, community-driven project?
-   **Kaze's Game Design Philosophy:** Expand on his views regarding player experience, difficulty balancing (e.g., "skill gap"), the role of tutorials/prompts, and his critiques of common game design tropes (e.g., "chores").
-   **The Future of "Return to Yoshi's Island" and ROM Hacking:** Discuss his long-term vision for the project, anticipated challenges beyond the current boss, and his broader thoughts on the SM64 decompilation's impact on the ROM hacking scene.

## Game Development Process
- The development is highly iterative, with Kaze primarily working on implementing and refining visual elements for Star Select screens (e.g., "Koopa Wave Cove," "Mouse Cave," "Bubble Dome") based on assets provided by collaborators.
- Significant progress is being made on these Star Select screens, involving animation, visual effects (fog, lighting, scrolling textures), and UI adjustments.
- A major milestone mentioned is the optimization of ROM space by 1.7 MB due to a tool from collaborator Arctic, allowing for more streamed music.
- Bug fixing is a continuous process, addressing issues like objects falling through floors, rendering errors, and animation glitches.
- Kaze often works through technical challenges live, such as N64 coordinate limitations forcing design changes (e.g., shortening a level element to prevent crashes).
- The order of asset creation and thus implementation can be driven by collaborator (Biobak's) preference: "it's basically just whatever biobank feels like making first gets made first."

## Personal Insights
- Kaze expresses a strong appreciation for high-quality art and music in games but believes game design is paramount (e.g., his opinion on Origami King: "the artists are so great the music is so great it's a shame that the game designers on this game are trash").
- He has a design philosophy of aiming for elegance and avoiding visual clutter, particularly in backgrounds: "We don't want the background to be too distracting... it kinda ruins the elegance of the background."
- Kaze is aware of his on-stream persona, acknowledging he can be "very easily irritated" but also quickly moves on.
- He shows a clear passion for N64 development, often diving into technical specifics and striving to push the console's capabilities.
- There's a recurring theme of wanting to create high-quality, polished experiences, evident in the detailed work on Star Select screens.

## Collaborator Information
- **Badub (Composer):** While not directly interacting in this stream, the successful ROM space optimization by Arctic is noted to allow for "more streamed music," which is Badub's domain. Kaze also mentions a plan to "buy the music and like pay the musician off," indicating an intent to compensate the composer.
- **Biobak (Graphics Artist):** Biobak is a key and active collaborator during the stream, providing 3D models, concepts, and feedback for various Star Select screens (Koopa Wave Cove, Mouse Cave, Koopa Carnival, Bubble Dome). Kaze spends much of the stream implementing and troubleshooting Biobak's assets (e.g., "Biobank modeled this at an insane scale," "Biobank feels like making first gets made first"). Biobak also suggests features and provides feedback live in chat (e.g., "move the text down," minecart animation).
- **Zeina (Animations):** Kaze mentions a future technical improvement: "as soon as we switch to Katerinian animations it's gonna be a lot less relevant." This suggests quaternion animations are planned, which would likely involve Zeina's expertise, though no direct contribution from Zeina is detailed in this specific stream.
- **Other Contributors:**
    - **Arctic:** A significant technical contributor. Arctic's tool "strm64" saved 1.7MB of ROM space, enabling more music. Kaze also consults Arctic's potential changes regarding music loop points ("did arctic remove the loop points").

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
- **N64 Hardware Limitations:** A recurring challenge. For example, the N64's 30,000-33,000 coordinate range limit forces Kaze to redesign elements to prevent crashes ("If you render any object out of this range your n64 is just gonna crash"). Performance and ROM size are constant considerations.
- **Implementing Visuals & Animations:** Significant effort goes into creating dynamic and visually appealing Star Select screens. This involves challenges like getting text scrolling right, implementing fog effects effectively, animating objects along splines (minecart), and ensuring smooth performance.
- **Bug Fixing:** Kaze encounters and resolves various bugs, from Mario falling through platforms ("Mario just falls through these and just dies") to rendering glitches and animation issues.
- **Design Philosophy:** Decisions are made to maintain visual clarity and elegance, such as avoiding overly cluttered backgrounds ("We don't want the background to be too distracting").
- **Scope Management:** Kaze mentions an idea for a "small sequel minigame to the yoshi racing simulator" but decides against it as it "doesn't fit the scope of this game."

## Business Aspects
- **Funding and Compensation:** Kaze is transparent about the limited profitability of his YouTube channel and Patreon ("My YouTube as it is, is already barely even profitable... $6.90 last month"). This impacts his ability to pay collaborators, though he expresses a desire to do so, especially for music ("That would like buy the music and like pay the musician off"). Biobak's payment is humorously mentioned as "$5 per vertex, which I can't afford."
- **Marketing/Promotion:** Primarily informal, through Kaze's YouTube streams and videos. He mentions an upcoming "banger video" that he hopes will "make the bucks," possibly for increased visibility or income.
- **Release/Distribution:** No specific plans for release or formal distribution are discussed in this transcript. The focus is on ongoing development.

## Key Quotes
- "Arctic realized yesterday that his tool strm64 has some cool properties that allow us to save 1.7 megabytes of ROM space... which means we are allowed to have more streamed music than we thought." (Highlights a significant technical breakthrough and collaborator impact)
- "We don't want the background to be too distracting I think that there's a very tempting force to just add more and more shit Until it's just a clusterfuck of stuff, but it kinda ruins the elegance of the background." (Reveals Kaze's design philosophy)
- "If you render any object out of this range your n64 is just gonna crash I will have to bring the fog nearer But you're going beyond this it's just a crash." (Illustrates a concrete N64 limitation dictating design)

## Potential Interview Topics
- **Vision for "Return to Yoshi's Island":** Explore Kaze's overarching creative goals for the game, what makes it unique, and its connection to the original Yoshi's Island.
- **The Collaborative Ecosystem:** Delve deeper into the dynamics of working with Biobak, Arctic, Badub, Zeina, and others. How are creative differences handled? How does remote collaboration shape the project?
- **Navigating N64's Frontiers:** Discuss the most significant technical challenges and innovative solutions Kaze has encountered/developed while pushing the N64's capabilities for this ambitious ROM hack.

- **The Role of Live Streaming in Development:** Discuss how the interactive nature of streaming, direct feedback from the community, and developing "in public" influences the game's direction and Kaze's process.

## Game Development Process
-   The stream shows active development on various aspects of "Return to Yoshi's Island," including boss fights (the "block boss," referred to sometimes as the "all-black boss"), cutscenes, star select screens, and specific level assets like a submarine and an animated bird for a level select backdrop.
-   Development involves iterative cycles of implementation, testing, and refinement, often in direct response to collaborator feedback (e.g., Biomech's requests for visuals).
-   Significant time is spent on debugging and troubleshooting technical issues related to N64 hardware limitations, custom tools (Fast64), rendering, and animation.
-   Kaze mentions working on significant portions of the game, like the "All-Black Boss," off-stream.
-   There's a clear process of planning and designing new game areas, such as level themes and "Retro Sections."
-   Kaze is moving to a new house, which will temporarily affect his streaming schedule but will result in a new dedicated workspace ("Kaze dungeon").

## Personal Insights
-   Kaze expresses a strong desire to understand the root cause of technical problems rather than just finding a workaround: "You can't just be like, oh it works good enough. You have to be like why the fuck is it not doing what I expect? to do."
-   He values his community's engagement but maintains creative control, often injecting humor into his interactions and decisions regarding the stream itself (e.g., "I thought this was funnier" regarding stream title).
-   He has opinions on game design elements ("Music level sounds like shit. I don't actually like that idea.") and isn't afraid to voice them or change plans.
-   Kaze shows pride in his work, particularly when his YouTube content performs well: "This one's doing numbers... This video got more views in like not even two hours than most videos get like a day."
-   He reflects on the nature of game development: "Honestly, people say that everything in game development takes so long, but considering how big of a part this game is, and how much we just got done here, doesn't seem that much of a big deal to me."

## Collaborator Information
-   **Badub:** No relevant information found in this transcript.
-   **Biobak (Biomech):** Appears to be a key collaborator, likely responsible for graphics, visual design, and specific asset requests. Kaze spends significant time implementing and troubleshooting Biobak's requests, such as animations for the star select screen, lighting effects, and the submarine. There's a direct back-and-forth: "This is not the fuck biomech wanted," "Okay, I think this is doing the thing that Biobank wants." Biobak also seems to work on star select screens independently ("Let's look at bio bags other star selects").
-   **Zeina:** Mentioned in the context of a previous project ("Donkey Donkey Mario 64," where she apparently contributed to dialogue: "No, seriously, who made the dialogue for that toad? I will not disclose. I will protect their identity. Haha.") and as someone Kaze plays games with. Her direct involvement in "Return to Yoshi's Island" is not detailed in this transcript beyond being a known associate Kaze interacts with.
-   **Other Contributors:**
    -   **Skellux:** Mentioned as the inspiration for the "pink bob-omb" character in Kaze's previous game, "Donkey Donkey Mario 64."
    -   **Master True:** Kaze mentions seeing "Runmic being made" by him, possibly referring to a tool or technique.

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
-   **Boss Design:** The "block boss" fight is being worked on, with considerations for difficulty ("this boss is a bit too hard right now, especially once we add these things going down") and introductory cutscenes.
-   **Level Themes:** Active discussion and decision-making on level themes, including ideas like Wild West, casino, comic book superhero, Arctic/ice cream, and desert island. Some ideas are rejected (e.g., music level, Minus World).
-   **Retro Sections:** Plans for several "Retro Sections" based on classic Nintendo games: Paper Mario 64 (Goomba Town), Mario Paint, Dr. Mario, Mario Land 1, and Smash 64. Kaze is open to changing these if better ideas emerge.
-   **Technical Challenges:**
    -   Frequent rendering issues, including problems with vertex colors, combiners, and texture formats ("This is gonna look a little crunchy on the n64").
    -   A significant bug with a sine wave function due to a compiler issue where it linked "garbage data" without warning about a missing include (`math.h`).
    -   Debugging animation logic, such as the bird's take-off sequence on the level select screen ("Everything just freezes when I press A").
    -   Optimizing performance ("setting fuck on every single one of these it's kind of bad performance wise").
-   **Asset Creation & Animation:** Detailed work on animating a submarine with sine waves and a bird for a level select screen, including troubleshooting visual glitches and behavior.
-   **Star Placement:** A design guideline is mentioned: "in RTY I actually have the guideline that every star is exactly 300 rounds off the floor... Or no, every star is 200 floors, boxes are 300."
-   **Overworld Design:** The overworld is planned for a complete rework, with a "tropical island" theme inspired by Mario Party.

## Business Aspects
-   **YouTube Content:** Kaze monitors the performance of his YouTube videos ("This one's doing numbers") and mentions an upcoming video on the "fast inverse square root algorithm." This suggests YouTube is an important platform for outreach and community engagement.
-   **Streaming:** Decisions about stream titles and content are made with an eye for engagement and humor. He mentions an upcoming move and potential "bonus streams" or a week off, indicating streaming is a regular commitment.
-   **Monetization (Minor):** Briefly dismisses pinning a comment for money ("The views I lose from having unnecessary stuff like that pinned is far outweighing your five bucks."), but humorously adds "Actually do send me the money, but I'm still not doing it." This suggests direct fan funding isn't a primary driver for in-stream decisions.
-   **Release/Distribution:** No specific plans for release date or distribution methods are mentioned in this transcript, beyond the ongoing development of the ROM hack itself.

## Key Quotes
-   "You can't just be like, oh it works good enough. You have to be like why the fuck is it not doing what I expect? to do." (Reflects Kaze's dedication to understanding and solving technical issues thoroughly.)
-   "What the fuck how can it just link garbage data and not tell me... Because I would did not include the sine function needed for this and it still compiled the sine function somehow out of nothing." (Highlights a particularly frustrating and perplexing technical challenge.)

*Extracted on: 20231028*

## Game Development Process
- The game is actively being developed, with Kaze mentioning, "since the last stream I made so many updates to this game."
- A significant performance improvement (10-15%) was recently achieved, primarily by changing how coins are rendered (from billboards to screen-space sprites). Kaze states, "At this stage, that is crazy. I don't think we will ever see another performance improvement this big. Until we implement F3DX3."
- Development is progressing on new levels, with "Course 11" (the power plant) being the current focus for design and implementation of new platforming mechanics.
- Kaze has a clear plan for the structure of new levels, for example, for the power plant: "I have all five sections here planned out and I have two rooms sketched."
- The game uses custom music: "all music in this game is custom so we're not reusing some other games music."
- There's an ongoing effort to improve visuals, with some levels being reworked by collaborators.
- The codebase uses some unique approaches, like a "tick function instead of a behavior loop" and a new way to declare variables that Kaze believes is "way more transparent."

## Personal Insights
- Kaze's primary motivation is creative expression and fun: "I'm not trying to send a message at all, I just want to make the funny Mario."
- Development is a passion project done in his spare time: "I have a full time job, I can't spend that much time working on this right now. Unfortunately." This impacts the development timeline.
- He has strong opinions on game design, preferring intrinsic rewards and innovative concepts over simple collection mechanics: "I want the game that rewards me with finding cool shit. I want to see cool concepts, not extrinsic motivation like, oh, number go up."
- Kaze expresses frustration with frequent questions about release dates, emphasizing an "it's done when it's done" philosophy.
- He sometimes struggles with the technical aspects of streaming (OBS issues, mouse problems) and physical discomfort (neck pain).
- Kaze seems to value responsiveness in controls: "I feel like that would make this less responsive. You know what I mean? It's kinda nice how responsive this is."

## Collaborator Information
- **Badub (composer):** No specific mention of "Badub" as the composer in this transcript. Kaze states all music is custom, and later mentions "Dumpy" (a composer for another project) and speculates about needing a new composer in the future, implying the current composer isn't named or he might be doing it himself.
- **Biobak (graphics artist, also referred to as Biomech/Biobank):**
    - Actively contributes design ideas: "I agree with Biobank's idea to make the soap go to the outside cages instead, though. I think that's a good change."
    - Kaze plans to delegate texture work to him for the power plant level: "I Will leave the textures to buy a bike [Biobak] but I will pick something for now that doesn't look completely awful at least."
    - Biobak also participates in community discussions, e.g., posting a "toaster speedrun."
- **Zeina (animations):**
    - Her role in animations is not detailed in this transcript.
    - She is mentioned in a personal context: "Zena has banished me here [to the basement]. She said I'm not allowed to come up unless it's to grab food."
- **Other Contributors:**
    - **Nata (also referred to as Mata):** Tasked with reworking the visuals for the "bomb cap factory" level. "Nata wants to rework it. He's gonna have it finished by the start of June." However, Kaze expresses some doubt about the progress: "he is four months overtime on something that he said would take him two weeks. So my confidence in this is not very high." Kaze also mentions paying Nata for this commission.
    - **Yoshi Milkman:** Contributing new custom sound effects. "Dude, we're going to have Yoshi Milkman's new sound soon, actually... Yoshi Milkman made so many new sounds for Mario 64 that are going to be pretty good. It's going to make the game feel a little more immersive."

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
- **Performance Optimization:** A major focus, exemplified by the coin rendering change (billboards to screen-space sprites) resulting in a 10-15% FPS boost in areas like "Bunny Brushworks."
- **Level Design (Power Plant - Course 11):**
    - Planned introduction of three new platform types: treadmills, dangling platforms, and collapsing grates, culminating in a final room that combines them.
    - A "weight platform" mechanic was developed during the stream, where one platform goes down as another goes up, based on Mario's position. This idea came from Biobak and was adopted: "I think we're going with that idea, yes. I like that."
    - Visual theme: Kaze is looking for an "abandoned power plant" vibe, referencing industrial imagery with pipe structures. He wants to avoid a "grainy" or "noisy" visual style.
- **Difficulty and Controls:** Aiming for a difficulty comparable to vanilla Mario 64, but acknowledging that the game's improved controls might make seemingly harder challenges more manageable. "Although, keep in mind, the controls in this work a lot better."
- **Black Boss (Course 11):** A boss fight where the boss is oil-slicked and rainbow-colored. Mechanics include running out of "soap" and dodging platforms. Kaze took Biobak's suggestion to change where the soap spawns.
- **New Star Model:** A new, non-transparent star model has been implemented, which Kaze believes is "a lot nicer than the transparent star in Vanilla Mar 64."
- **Implementing Platform Mechanics:** Kaze discusses the technical challenges of making dangling platforms move and interact realistically, considering animations vs. geo layouts. He also fine-tunes the physics of the weight platforms to make them feel responsive and useful for gameplay.

## Business Aspects
- **Release Date:** Kaze firmly states there are no release dates. "I'm not gonna guarantee any release dates... You're just gonna have to wait until it's done." He reiterates, "It's done when it's done."
- **Funding/Commissions:** Kaze mentions paying a collaborator: "See, the thing is, I paid him [Nata] to reorganize. He asked me for a commission because he needed some money." This is the only mention of financial transactions related to the game's development.
- **Marketing/Distribution:** No direct mentions of marketing plans or distribution strategies. The project appears to be a passion-driven endeavor shared via streams.

## Key Quotes
- "Dude, since the last stream I made so many updates to this game. Oh, you guys have no idea. We found like a 10-15% performance improvement. At this stage, that is crazy." (Shows rapid progress and technical achievement)
- "I'm not trying to send a message at all, I just want to make the funny Mario." (Highlights Kaze's core motivation)
- "I have a full time job, I can't dedicate that much time to just working on this. You're just gonna have to wait until it's done." (Explains development constraints and stance on release)
- "Okay, so our next mission here is to make the power plant... I have all five sections here planned out and I have two rooms sketched." (Illustrates methodical level design approach)

## Potential Interview Topics
- **The Genesis of "Return to Yoshi's Island":** Explore the initial inspiration for the hack, why Yoshi's Island, and the decision to use the Mario 64 decompilation.
- **Collaborative Dynamics:** Delve deeper into how Kaze works with Biobak, Nata, Yoshi Milkman, and potentially Zeina. How are tasks managed, creative visions aligned, and challenges (like Nata's delays) handled?

*Extracted on: 20231104*

## Game Development Process
-   Kaze is actively working on a level for "Return to Yoshi's Island," specifically the "power plant area from the oil level."
-   Current development tasks include programming interactive level elements like platforms (elevators, treadmills), designing the level layout, and implementing enemy behaviors.
-   Significant time is spent on debugging and problem-solving, such as fixing non-functional platforms, addressing overlapping objects, and resolving texture scrolling issues.
-   Optimization is an ongoing concern, with mentions of efforts to improve frame rates (e.g., "We went from 43 to 45 fps to the range of 45 to 49 fps").
-   The process is iterative, involving trying out ideas, testing them, identifying issues, and refining the implementation.
-   Future work planned includes programming specific enemies like "amps" and "oil fuzzies" with unique mechanics.
-   Kaze mentions making "mini optimizations over the week" like inlining functions.

## Personal Insights
-   Kaze expresses a desire for streams to be free of constant release date inquiries: "I hope we can go a whole stream without people asking me for release dates every 15 minutes that would be pretty nice."
-   He reflects on his audience's shift towards more technical viewers: "I feel like a lot of programmers watch my channel now and not so much the casual audience ever since the source code revert."
-   He shows a pragmatic side regarding project selection, weighing passion against potential financial success for smaller projects: "I also don't want to work on hacks that are not gonna be a financial success So we do have to find something topical or something clickbaity like Mario 64 level but good."
-   Kaze has a structured approach to creating his YouTube video content, aiming for engaging narratives: "It's a five-step act first. We hook in the viewer...Then second We're gonna start building tension..."
-   He values the "vibe" of a level and finds it challenging to design without the final textures.

## Collaborator Information
-   **Badub (composer):** No relevant information found in this transcript.
-   **Biobak (graphics artist):**
    -   Expected to provide textures and rework the visuals for the level Kaze is currently working on. Kaze states, "I'm gonna just pick random textures. I'll change them when I rework the level" and "I guess this whole area is gonna be ugly until biobank gets to it."
    -   Biobak seems to have input on visual elements, as Kaze mentions a discussion about some assets: "What will you replace them with biobank? Nothing they don't look good. Oh damn."
-   **Zeina (animations):**
    -   Mentioned in a personal context: "yeah Zena is finally out of my hair she is upstairs now and I'm downstairs isn't that nice."
    -   No direct mention of her contributing animations to "Return to Yoshi's Island" in this specific transcript.
-   **Other Contributors (from chat, actively involved in the stream):**
    -   **"Mario" (chat user):** Kaze consults with this user regarding texture choices: "Mario did you end up um picking any textures for this because otherwise I might have to try some more."
    -   **"Lila" (chat user):** Provides significant real-time technical suggestions, helps with debugging, and discusses technical implementation details with Kaze. Kaze frequently addresses Lila's input directly (e.g., "Okay, Lila, I believe you that this feature may work but I don't see how").

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
-   **Level Design & Flow:**
    -   Designing the "power plant" area, focusing on platforming sequences involving elements like an elevator and a fast-moving treadmill. "This is the power plant area from the oil level so if you go inside the whole power generator gonna have to platform through it."
    -   Balancing difficulty and player experience, such as adjusting treadmill speed ("Mario's moving a little fast. I need to slow down a bit") and ensuring platforming sections are clearable but challenging.
    -   Addressing camera issues in tight spaces: "The problem here is that the camera also kind of sucks, right? I don't like that. You can't see Mario."
-   **Enemy Design & Mechanics:**
    -   Conceptualizing an "oil fuzzy" enemy inspired by "Touch fuzzy get dizzy" from Yoshi's Island.
    -   Planned effects for the oil fuzzy include making Mario slippery and uncontrollable, inducing visual distortions (wobbly screen, rainbow oil texture, FOV changes), slowing down audio, and potentially exaggerating Mario's squash and stretch animations.
    -   Planning to include "amp" enemies, possibly with dynamic lighting effects and movement along splines.
-   **Puzzle Elements:**
    -   Designing a Yoshi coin collectible that requires a specific interaction with a moving platform: "Imagine a Yoshi coin like somewhere up here... And the only way to get it would be to pull this platform down and then like hit it something like that."
-   **Technical Implementation Challenges:**
    -   Debugging platform behavior, such as an elevator not moving due to overlapping, identical platforms.
    -   Correcting texture scrolling bugs: "How is there a texture scroll here I literally removed it."
    -   Ensuring performance targets are met while adding new features.
-   **Aesthetics and "Vibe":**
    -   Struggling to define the level's atmosphere without final textures from Biobak: "So that's kind of really difficult for me because I can't really estimate the vibe of this, you know i'm kind of When I design a level I kind of have to go with the vibe."

## Business Aspects
-   **Financial Considerations for Projects:** Kaze mentions that some large projects (like an OOT remaster) would require "decent financial incentive." He also states a preference for smaller, pre-RTYI demo projects to be "a financial success" or at least "topical or something clickbaity."
-   **Pre-Release Demos for RTYI:** Plans to release "one or two more demos" before RTYI. The purpose is "so people can just Play test the physics and stuff." These demos might focus on popular Mario 64 levels, remade.
-   **YouTube Content Strategy:** Kaze consciously thinks about how to structure his videos for viewer engagement, aiming for content that might perform well algorithmically (e.g., "I'm working on a video on the Indra square root I think it might do okay on YouTube").
-   **Professional Work (GFB/Yogscast Games):** Kaze confirms he is "still actively working there" but is under NDA regarding specific projects: "I Am NOT allowed to tell what I am working on."

## Key Quotes
-   "I think we were programming all the platforms here right I just made this one here and now I need to program it this one should be pretty easy to program I think I'll program it as an object just so now she and everything works right off the bat." (Illustrates his object-oriented approach and iterative building).
-   "Honestly before our tyi's release. I do want to release one or two more demos where people can just Play test the physics and stuff... But I also don't want to work on hacks that are not gonna be a financial success So we do have to find something topical or something clickbaity." (Highlights the dual purpose of demos and his business-minded approach to smaller projects).
-   "Touch fuzzy get dizzy. Oh They should make Marsh super slippery so you can't stop yes, I like that... The weird Effect happens should you take damage to a Lot of squash and stretch... Mario's squash and stretch effects becomes 5x strong... Also increase the strength of the rainbow effect on the oil That will look wild." (Shows the creative brainstorming process for unique enemy mechanics in RTYI).

*Extracted on: 20231111*

## Game Development Process
- The project "Return to Yoshi's Island" (RTYI) is actively in development, with a significant portion of levels still needing completion (Kaze mentions "we need to finish like nine levels I think").
- Development involves a systematic bug-fixing process, tackling issues course by course. Kaze mentions having stopped at "course 4" in his bug-fixing pass.
- Asset integration from collaborators is a key activity, involving importing models, textures, and animations.
- A significant amount of time is spent on troubleshooting technical issues, including N64-specific bugs (e.g., "geo bone" system, sound computation), exporter problems (Blender plugins), and unexpected behaviors in custom code.
- Iteration is constant: new features or optimizations can break existing content, requiring ongoing maintenance ("we often break a lot of old stuff").
- Kaze mentions that RTYI might be "75% done" (a figure attributed to Lila, which Kaze contextualizes regarding her specific tasks) but focuses on the remaining work rather than a fixed percentage.
- Development includes creating new tools or plugins, like the "mini n64 object exporter" for Blender, to achieve specific animation goals.

## Personal Insights
- Kaze prioritizes player "excitement" over raw "difficulty" in game design, aiming for engaging experiences rather than frustrating challenges.
- He reflects on past projects like "Lost Impact," acknowledging that his earlier, less compromising approach to implementing every idea sometimes led to suboptimal game design.
- Kaze believes in rapid prototyping and feedback for learning game design: "spam games... spending two weeks on each get a bunch of feedback."
- He expresses a desire for efficiency, both in personal habits (like disliking time-inefficient barbers) and in development (e.g., optimizing N64 matrix multiplications).
- Kaze has a clear vision for his future, seeing RTYI as a stepping stone and "advertisement" for an original IP he plans to develop and fund via Kickstarter.
- He shows a mix of confidence in his skills (e.g., Unreal Engine programming) and candidness about ongoing challenges and learning.

## Collaborator Information
- **Badub (Composer):** No relevant information found in this transcript. (The prompt mentioned Badub as the composer).
- **Biobak (Biomech - Graphics Artist):**
    - A significant contributor of 3D models and textures. Kaze states, "the biobank made a bunch of stuff for us that we need."
    - Assets mentioned include Amps, the airplane, a "cell guy" (Shy Guy variant), the speed ring, and textures for the airplane's propeller and dust trail.
    - Kaze integrates Biobak's assets, sometimes needing to adjust them or discuss design choices (e.g., airplane dust trail texture).
- **Zeina (Zena - Animations):**
    - Responsible for character animations. Kaze mentions, "I need the animations finished from Zena first We need to finish the penguins mission."
    - Specific animations cited include those for penguins and Dory. Kaze notes that "all the penguins need animations" and refers to Dory's animations as being "fucked up animation wise" due to the old geo bones system.
    - Zena was present at Kaze's house during the stream.
- **Other Contributors:**
    - **Lila:** An active and knowledgeable chat participant whom Kaze mentions is "working on tools right now that is way more valuable" than finishing a "match." She engages in technical discussions about texture formats and Blender issues.
    - **Rionno:** Mentioned as a "professionally educated game translator" who will be doing the Spanish translation for RTYI.
    - **That Cozy:** Creator of the "mini n64 object exporter" Blender plugin that Kaze attempts to use.
    - **Zerovolt:** Kaze mentions potentially hiring Zerovolt to "make music" for his future original IP.
    - Chat participants like "Mr. Common," "Holly," "Sam," "P4 DD" provide feedback or engage in discussions, illustrating community interaction.

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
- **Feature Removal for User Experience:** The "instant pause exit" feature was removed "so that bad players don't accidentally exit levels," showing a consideration for broader player accessibility.
- **Balancing Difficulty and Engagement:** The airplane minigame is designed to be "difficult to control" but the mission itself "very easy to pass." The falling platform sequence is intended to "feel a lot more intense without actually making it more difficult."
- **N64 Technical Limitations:**
    - Constant struggle with optimizing for the N64, such as discussions around texture formats (IA4 vs. IA8, CI4, CI8) balancing detail, color depth, and memory/performance.
    - Fixing legacy N64 engine bugs like the "geo bone" issue to save on matrix multiplications.
    - A sound bug where distant actors' sounds play as if right on top of the camera due to issues in sound computation.
- **Tooling and Workflow Issues:**
    - Significant time spent troubleshooting Blender exporters (e.g., the "mini n64 object exporter" not working with a newer Blender version).
    - Losing texture data because it was "just bytes" and needing to recreate or find previous versions.
- **Iterative Design and Bug Fixing:**
    - "Random rock" spawner not working as intended, only spawning one type of rock.
    - Mario's shadow missing, warps being too small due to parameter overrides.
    - A "floor" collision bug discovered and fixed live.
    - Refining the airplane's dust trail effect involved tweaking combiners and textures.
- **Level Design Philosophy:** Kaze aims for "purpose" in level design, with some sections designed primarily as "a cool set piece that looks cool to look at." He's willing to adjust difficulty down if a section feels frustrating over solid ground.
- **Camera Considerations:** Aware of how camera placement can negatively impact platforming, Kaze makes adjustments to improve it.

## Business Aspects
- **Future Original IP and Kickstarter:** Kaze explicitly plans to "announce our own game project our own IP and we're gonna make a kickstarter there" shortly before or upon RTYI's release.
- **RTYI as Marketing:** RTYI is viewed as a major project that will serve as "advertisement" for this future original game, leveraging its potential popularity.
- **Team Expansion Plans:** The Kickstarter funds would be used to "hire a bunch of people," including potentially Zerovolt for music and Biobak for level design.
- **Social Media Strategy:** Kaze discusses using Twitter for promotion closer to release, being mindful of algorithm impacts (e.g., not directly linking YouTube to avoid deprioritization). He acknowledges Twitter's role in gaining views for past content.
- **Monetization:** Donations are received during the stream, indicating a form of direct community support.

## Key Quotes
- "I just don't think difficulty is good. I don't want difficulty. I want excitement. You know what I mean?" (Kaze's game design philosophy)
- "See the thing is when we work on a new level or new optimizations, we often break a lot of old stuff So a lot of old levels are really broken right now." (On the iterative and sometimes challenging nature of game development)
- "Return to Yoshi's Island you think it might be my biggest project ever it will be the advertisement... then when Return to Yoshi's Island launches we also launch the kickstarter for the own game and then I can hire a bunch of people." (On the strategic plan for RTYI and future projects)
