*Extracted on: 20240120*

## Game Development Process
- Kaze is actively working on the "saloon" level, including a secret room and an attached cave system intended for a minecart chase sequence.
- Significant progress includes importing most of the saloon level, implementing new dialogue cutscenes, and working on net physics.
- The "pirate ship" level is described as "mostly done," awaiting final animations and improved flame effects.
- Development involves iterative design, asset integration (Shy Guys, barrels, textures), and fixing technical issues (vertex shading, rendering bugs, missing textures).
- Kaze mentions starting development of "Return to Yoshi's Island" (RTYI) around mid-2020.
- Optimization is an ongoing concern, with work on the room system to reduce lag and efforts to manage polygon counts (e.g., "reduce so many condition vertices").

## Personal Insights
- Kaze has strong opinions on game monetization, preferring to release the game for free and open source, with potential "souvenir" sales (like an OST cartridge) over direct game sales.
- He is passionate about achieving a high level of polish, stating, "The background's gonna make this level go from like 9 out of 10 to 10 out of 10."
- Kaze is candid about external challenges, such as Nintendo taking down over 70 of his videos, which he feels has hindered his channel's growth.
- He often engages in philosophical or tangential discussions with his chat, covering topics from eternal life to critiques of consumerism and views on porn addiction.
- He values community interaction, taking suggestions from chat (e.g., camera ideas, dialogue lines) and discussing feedback.

## Collaborator Information
- **Badub (composer):** No specific contributions or interactions were mentioned in this transcript excerpt for "Return to Yoshi's Island."
- **Biobak (graphics artist):** Kaze discusses changes made to Shy Guy models, implying they were assets received from a collaborator ("Did I change anything from what you've sent? I changed the Shy Guys a little bit..."). A chatter named "Biobank" (highly likely to be Biobak) also actively contributes ideas during the stream, such as a pun-based dialogue line ("We do things the murky way" -> "milky way").
- **Zeina (animator):** Mentioned as being responsible for animations (e.g., "pirate ship is mostly done. I'm just missing a few jelly block animation frames" likely by Zeina) and was expected to provide 3D models, specifically "milk bottles" for the saloon level, though Kaze notes, "I guess she forgot."
- **Other Contributors:**
    - **LibDragon dev(s):** Kaze mentions occasionally talking to a developer from the LibDragon project about N64 optimizations and sharing ideas.
    - **James Lambert:** Mentioned for creating a "very cool technical thing" on N64 (Megatech), though not directly a contributor to RTYI.

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
- **Saloon Secret Room & Minecart Chase:** A significant portion of the stream focuses on designing a secret "choccy milk" speakeasy in the saloon, leading to a minecart chase sequence through an adjoining cave. This involves brainstorming:
    - The narrative hook (illegal choccy milk).
    - The trigger for the chase (Shy Guys getting caught and fleeing).
    - Mechanics of the chase (Mario jumping between 3 separate minecarts, dodging projectiles from Snuffits).
    - The level layout for the cave and minecart track.
    - How to end the sequence (discussion around a fall vs. reaching an end platform, with a decision leaning towards a fall and then a fight).
- **Player Experience & Control:** Kaze is concerned with ensuring intuitive gameplay and preventing exploits. For example, deciding that landing on minecart tracks (off the carts) should result in "death" to keep the chase focused. He also debates camera controls (current third-person vs. full first-person).
- **Technical Challenges:**
    - **Rendering issues:** Problems with vertex shading (carpet), lighting flags on textures (barrels), and general rendering bugs with Glideon (e.g., on the minecart rails).
    - **Asset integration:** Adjusting combiners on Shy Guy models due to environment color issues, finding suitable textures for the cave.
    - **Physics:** Implementing generic net physics.
- **Maintaining Mario Feel:** Kaze emphasizes keeping the gameplay platforming-based, stating, "I like it to still be platforming based is the thing. I don't really want to give Mario a gun."
- **Discoverability:** Designing hidden elements, like the secret saloon door, to be discoverable through NPC dialogue and environmental clues.

## Business Aspects
- The game "Return to Yoshi's Island" will be released for **free** and will be **open source**.
- Kaze has considered a potential monetization strategy: selling a physical version of the game's Original Soundtrack (OST) on a cartridge, complete with a box and instruction manual, marketed as a "souvenir."
- He explicitly states, "I actually think video games should not be monetized off of video game sales. I think that's a stupid concept."
- Kaze mentions that Nintendo has taken down over 70 of his videos, impacting his channel's visibility and perceived as "sabotage."

## Key Quotes
- "The background's gonna make this level go from like 9 out of 10 to 10 out of 10." (Illustrates dedication to polish)
- "I actually think video games should not be monetized off of video game sales... I think maybe you should sell souvenirs of your video games." (Highlights Kaze's philosophy on monetization)
- "So today what we have to do is we're gonna have to make the secret room in the saloon... We're gonna go through it and then we'll cut into a room where a bunch of cowboys are hanging out and they're secretly drinking choccy milk, which is illegal in this world." (Shows the creative, humorous, and narrative-driven design process)
- "I'm gonna make it so that if you land on the rails, you're just gonna die. That's literally it there's no argument about this." (Demonstrates decisive problem-solving to maintain intended gameplay flow)

## Potential Interview Topics
- **The Creative Vision for "Return to Yoshi's Island":** Explore the core inspiration behind the game, its unique thematic elements (like the "choccy milk" prohibition), and what Kaze hopes players will experience.
- **Collaborative Workflow and Challenges:** Delve deeper into the dynamic with collaborators like Zeina and Biobak, the process of integrating their work, and any unique challenges or benefits of their remote, informal team structure.
- **Designing the Minecart Chase Sequence:** A detailed discussion about the iteration and problem-solving involved in creating this specific set-piece, from initial concept to the planned platforming mechanics and technical implementation.
- **Philosophy on Open Source and Fan Games:** Kaze's decision to make RTYI free and open source, his views on game preservation/modification, and his experiences navigating the fan game space, especially concerning Nintendo's policies.
- **Technical Innovation and "Orgy.ai":** Discuss the development and advantages of his custom engine (Orgy.ai) for N64 ROM hacking, and any specific technical achievements or hurdles overcome in RTYI.

## Game Development Process
- Kaze is actively working on a specific "cowboy level," focusing on a complex minecart sequence.
- Current stage involves programming core mechanics and interactions, with visual polish and some asset creation (e.g., "milk bottles" by Zeina) happening concurrently or planned.
- Integration of graphical assets from collaborators (e.g., Biobak's "biomex things") is ongoing.
- The process is highly iterative, involving coding, testing, identifying issues, and redesigning gameplay segments (e.g., the minecart chase).
- Kaze mentions working on the level for "the last two weeks" or "last week," indicating focused development periods on specific features.
- He utilizes a custom engine with features like setting camera angles on level entry.

## Personal Insights
- Kaze expresses strong passion and enthusiasm for visually appealing elements he creates or incorporates: "Yeah, dude, I love this the fucking moon up there. Oh my god, this is so sexy."
- He believes in making changes for better player experience, even if it deviates from original game mechanics: "I Also made it so that red coin stars don't put you out of the stage anymore, I think that was a necessary change."
- He takes pride in the technical achievements of the project: "The crazy part is the game doesn't look like it can run on an N64 but it does."
- He has a critical view on certain game development practices and player skill: "I think people are just such bad gamers that they can't tell when their analog 3d platformers don't have analog controls it's like serving a soup full of piss to people that just have never had good food in their life they're not gonna notice it's full of piss."
- He reflects on his content creation strategy for YouTube: "Making level previews on YouTube is just not a good business model. I have to make technical videos, unfortunately."

## Collaborator Information
- **Badub (Composer):** No relevant information found in this transcript.
- **Biobak (Graphics Artist):**
    - Provides graphical assets referred to as "biomex things" that Kaze is importing into the level.
    - Kaze directly addresses Biobak ("biomeg") in the chat regarding these assets: "oh yeah biomeg you’re like the first person is this what you wanted i think it’s good."
- **Zeina (Animations/Assets):**
    - Tasked with creating specific in-game assets: "oh, yeah Zena Then you make milk bottles. I need them We need milk bottles."
    - Appears to be in the same physical location or working environment as Kaze during the stream, as Kaze comments on noise she's making: "Oh, what is that ungodly noise? What the fuck is Xena doing up there?" and later "no dude zana you were so loud earlier you were at the furnace earlier."
- **Other Contributors:** No other specific game development contributors are clearly identified or their roles detailed in this transcript.

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
- **Red Coin Stars:** Changed so they no longer eject the player from the stage, considered a "necessary change" for player experience.
- **100 Coin Stars:** Kaze states, "I don't think 100 coin stars should be in this game." Red coins, if they existed, would also not boot the player out.
- **Minecart Sequence (Cowboy Level):**
    - **Initial Concept:** Shy Guys/Snifits in minecarts, Mario jumps between them.
    - **Challenge:** Swapping between minecarts proved "really, really difficult" for the player.
    - **Iteration 1:** Mario on one large minecart platform, with Shy Guys in smaller carts.
    - **Challenge:** Player potentially getting squished on tracks or falling off unfairly.
    - **Iteration 2 (Solution):** Implemented a cutscene for the Shy Guys jumping into their carts to control the setup and prevent the player from jumping in too early or getting unfairly hit. The player's minecart movement is then managed relative to the Shy Guy carts.
    - **Ongoing Challenge:** Fine-tuning the speed, spacing, and behavior of the minecarts to make the chase engaging and fair. Debugging issues like carts crashing or Mario falling off.
- **Camera Control:**
    - Issue with doors letting the camera through: "I feel like doors should never let the camera through."
    - Debugging camera clipping during cutscenes, requiring adjustments to room geometry and camera flags.
- **Character Movement & Physics:**
    - Addressed "jittery motions" of characters by decoupling face angle from move angle.
    - Implemented and debugged an "align to surface" function for Mario.
    - Strong emphasis on proper analog stick control for movement.
- **Sound Design:** Implemented new sound effects for actions like ground pound jump (from Mario Kart 64), spin jump (Melee-inspired), and a new falling sound, actively seeking feedback from chat.

## Business Aspects
- **Monetization & Finances:**
    - Kaze is exploring Twitter monetization: "Dude I actually looked into Twitter monetization today It looks like if I could monetize my Twitter account, that'd be like $200 a month."
    - Considering hiring a social media manager, possibly on a revenue-sharing basis.
    - Experiencing issues with PayPal: "I'm I'm getting PayPal cocked they refused to let me use my PayPal money."
- **Content Strategy (YouTube):**
    - Believes "Making level previews on YouTube is just not a good business model."
    - Prefers making "technical videos" for better engagement/viability.
- **Distribution:** No specific plans for release or distribution of "Return to Yoshi's Island" are mentioned in this transcript, beyond the general context of ROM hacking.

## Key Quotes
- "The crazy part is the game doesn't look like it can run on an N64 but it does." (Highlights technical ambition and achievement)
- "Okay, but swapping between Minecarts is really, really difficult. Holy shit. I can't expect players to do that. How do we make this better?" (Illustrates the iterative design process and focus on playability)
- "I want to make sure no one gets stuck ever. Luigi mode. We call it little brother mode, but you know, you are the little brother." (Humorous take on accessibility, though later ideas are more serious)

## Potential Interview Topics
- **The Philosophy of Player Experience:** Explore Kaze's reasoning behind design choices like the red coin star change and his strong opinions on analog controls. How does he define "good" player experience in a challenging ROM hack?
- **Iterative Design in Action - The Minecart Saga:** A deeper dive into the multi-stage redesign of the minecart sequence. What were the core problems at each stage, and how did he arrive at the solutions? What does this reveal about his problem-solving approach?
- **Collaborative Dynamics:** How does Kaze manage and integrate contributions from artists like Biobak and Zeina? What is the workflow like, and how are creative differences or technical challenges resolved in a team setting for a ROM hack?

- **The Independent Creator's Journey:** Discuss the balance between passionate game development and the practicalities of monetization (Twitter, PayPal issues) and content strategy (YouTube). How does he sustain his work?

*Extracted on: 20240203*

## Game Development Process
-   The game is in a significant development phase, focusing on overhauling core mechanics, notably a complete rewrite of Mario's collision system and implementation of a new "step function" for movement.
-   Kaze mentions being in "course 12" and having "like three and a half levels left, basically," indicating substantial progress in level creation.
-   Specific missions, like the "minecart mission," are being finalized and showcased, though new systems are still introducing bugs (e.g., a crash during the minecart mission demo due to the new collision functions).
-   Development is iterative, with new systems being actively worked on, tested, and refined live on stream (e.g., the collision system was started "yesterday").
-   Work includes asset integration and refinement, such as setting up a bulletin board with textures made by Zeyna and designing NPC appearances.

## Personal Insights
-   Kaze believes Mario 64's movement design is "awesome," but the level design often lacks "placeness" (a distinct theme or vibe), which he aims to improve in "Return to Yoshi's Island."
-   He reflects on past projects, like "SM64 Madness," noting community perception about its "soul" despite its rapid development (two weeks).
-   Kaze values creating levels with a strong identity and theme, stating, "I think for places it's very important that the level has like a theme. A vibe. Something that you can identify the level with."
-   He expresses a desire for the new collision system to be "much better than any other Mario 64 thing."
-   He has a pragmatic approach to using existing assets if suitable: "we might as well just take assets from Google who cares... it'd hypocritical for us to like hack roms and then pretend like it's completely wrong to take assets."

## Collaborator Information
-   **Badub:**
    -   Mentioned as "making a lot of music" for the project.
    -   Kaze defers questions about music releases to Baduk ("you have to ask the dupe whenever he feels like it").
-   **Biobak:**
    -   Credited with "making a lot of stuff" for the hack, implying significant graphical or asset contributions.
-   **Zeina:**
    -   A key collaborator, physically present (upstairs in the same house during the stream).
    -   Contributes animations (e.g., the new spin jump animation, which Kaze then "polished").
    -   Creates textures and art assets (e.g., drawings for the bulletin board, textures for it, potentially designs for Koopa accessories like glasses and a cane).
    -   Engages in direct, often humorous, back-and-forth with Kaze during the stream regarding assets and game elements.
-   **Other Contributors:**
    -   **CDI and Zelda:** Mentioned as having provided help for Kaze's previous project, "Zelda Missing Link" ("I did have help from CDI and Zelda, which really helped the project."). It's not explicitly stated they are contributing to "Return to Yoshi's Island," but they are past collaborators.

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
-   **Collision System Overhaul:** A major undertaking to "rewrite Mario's collision entirely" for a more robust and improved feel. The new system uses binary searches, raycasts, and move verifications. Current challenges include bugs like incorrect animations on rollout and non-functional ceiling bonks.
-   **Spin Jump Animation:** The decision to use Mario's Down-B animation from Smash Melee for the spin jump, as the original "twirl looked bad" and the Melee version felt like the "closest you have to an official version... from 1996."
-   **Level Entrance Design (Monty Mole Boss):** Iterative design process for accessing a new area. Initial idea of a simple hole was dismissed. Explored options like a fake cardboard cutout boulder before settling on a breakable rock, potentially requiring a "bomb cap." The challenge is to make it discoverable but not overly obvious.
-   **NPC Design (Koopa Bankier):** Detailed discussion on creating a "Wild West bank employee" Koopa, including considerations for its appearance (baldness as a "vibe," beard style, glasses, clothing).
-   **Rendering and Technical Art:** Challenges with default material settings causing rendering issues ("Dude, I hate that this defaults to environment... it actually will render wrong"). Implementing "fog-shaded decals" and dealing with "coordinate quantization" for poster rendering.
-   **Dynamic Text Boxes:** A new feature where text boxes automatically resize to fit the dialogue content, showcased as a quality-of-life improvement.
-   **Yoshi Coins:** Replacing 100-coin stars, indicating a change in collectible philosophy.

## Business Aspects
-   Kaze acknowledges a "free dollar donation" from a viewer, suggesting informal monetary support via streaming.
-   He mentions that a video about the new complex collision system wouldn't be "marketable," indicating some awareness of content appeal, but this doesn't seem to drive core development decisions for the game itself.
-   No formal marketing, structured funding, or specific release/distribution plans were discussed.

## Key Quotes
-   "So, I had an idea yesterday to just rewrite Mario's collision entirely. What you're seeing right now is the rewritten collision... Once my new collision system is done, dude, this game will be so nice collision-wise, I think. Much better than any other Mario 64 thing."
-   "Yeah, I don't think Mario 64 is that great either, except for the movement design. Like the level design itself is not great, but the movement is like awesome. So that's the part I want to change."
-   "I think for places it's very important that the level has like a theme. A vibe. Something that you can identify the level with."
-   "We have like three and a half levels left, basically. We're in course 12 here."

-   **Achieving "Placeness" in Level Design:** Delve deeper into his concept of "placeness." How does this philosophy guide level creation in "Return to Yoshi's Island," and how does he differentiate his approach from the original Mario 64 levels?

*Extracted on: 20240210*

## Game Development Process
- Currently focused on the "cowboy level" (also referred to as "mole hideout"), specifically implementing Monty Mole enemy behavior and a boss fight.
- Significant off-stream progress is made; the stream often shows debugging and refinement.
- The game is stated to be approximately 80% complete, with "three more main courses and two side levels and one bowser level" remaining.
- Key development tasks include physics calculations for projectiles, AI behavior scripting, level scripting, and boss encounter design.
- A major milestone achieved is a completely new, more stable collision system, replacing the original Mario 64 one.
- Iterative development is evident, with Kaze working through bugs (e.g., rock spawning, moles shooting offset) and refining mechanics live.
- Star 1 and 2 for the current level are considered done, with work progressing on Star 3 ("Goomba imposter tower").

## Personal Insights
- Kaze expresses strong opinions on game mechanics, such as his disdain for the original SM64 collision system ("It is unusable") and his pride in his custom solution ("it's so much more stable").
- He has a nuanced philosophy on bugs: "if there's a bug in Mario 64 that you only encounter if you do it on purpose, I'll leave it in the game. But if it can happen on accident, I'll remove it." He specifically wants to keep BLJ possible if he can.
- Kaze values player experience and feeling over literal interpretations of critique: "I try to figure out like what the person was feeling that's wrong... seeing if I can address their feeling instead of their actual critique."
- He is ambitious, not only in overhauling core game systems but also in his future plans to develop an original commercial game.
- He is candid about the development process, including frustrations (e.g., with physics math) and moments of discovery.

## Collaborator Information
- **Badub (composer):** No specific mention of Badub or their contributions in this transcript segment.
- **Biobak (graphics artist):** No specific mention of Biobak or their contributions in this transcript segment.
- **Zeina (animator):**
    - Her animation work is implied as crucial for game polish. Kaze notes a "to do: add animations" for the Monty Moles, stating, "to effectively make this faster I think I need the animations."
    - A playful comment suggests "quaternion animations" are a known, perhaps complex, task ("Lila will only vote for you if you promise that you will force a few programmers to finish quaternion animations").
- **Other Contributors:**
    - **CX links:** Kaze asks, "Hello CX links, we already got any OST wishes today," which might imply CX links is involved with music selection or contribution, but their role is not clearly defined.

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
- **New Collision System:** A major decision to replace SM64's collision entirely due to its perceived instability. This new system is a point of pride but also led to unintended consequences like removing BLJ initially.
- **Projectile Physics:** Kaze struggled with calculating the Y-velocity for projectiles (rocks thrown by Moles), initially trying ChatGPT for help before solving it with manual physics equations. This involved understanding motion under gravity.
- **Boss Fight Design (Monty Moles):**
    - Initial ideas involved a set number of moles that get faster, or a survival wave. These were iterated upon due to concerns about being "boring" or visually cluttered.
    - The chosen design involves moles popping out of random holes, requiring the player to react. Kaze specifically scripted this behavior: "they pick a random hole to come out of."
    - Thematic consistency is considered (e.g., "No, I don't like hard hats, because this is a cowboy level").
- **Bug Fixing & Iteration:** Constant process of identifying and fixing bugs, such as moles shooting with an offset, interaction issues, and incorrect coin spawning.
- **Balancing Intentional vs. Accidental Bugs:** Kaze aims to remove bugs that hinder player experience accidentally but is open to keeping bugs that players seek out intentionally (like BLJ).
- **RAM Management:** Mentioned removing collision on a bridge in the cowboy level "for RAM reasons for now," indicating technical constraints of the N64 platform.

## Business Aspects
- **Future Original Game & Kickstarter:** Kaze explicitly states, "I'm planning like alongside the release of return to your silent I'll probably launch like a Kickstarter for my own game and then transition to working on that and then hopefully I can hire some other rom hackers to work on it with me actually."
- **Experience with Sponsorships:** Kaze recounts a negative experience with a company that sponsored an ad for a handheld device, indicating his awareness of his channel's value ("usually for an ad you get like $3,000"). This provides context for his potential approach to funding future projects.
- No direct marketing or distribution plans for "Return to Yoshi's Island" itself were mentioned in this transcript, which is typical for a ROM hack.

## Key Quotes
- "I made a completely new collision system. I said, fuck Mario 64's collision. It is unusable. We have our completely own collision system now. And it's so much more stable." (Highlights technical ambition and improvement over the original)
- "I'm not trying to prevent the BLJ. It's more so that just by making more stable physics, it just so happened to remove BLJ. And I consider that a bad thing, actually. Ideally, BLJ would still be possible." (Shows his design philosophy regarding iconic game mechanics and emergent play)
- "I mean the levels are left to make after this three more main courses and two side levels and one bowser level we're like 80% of the way there" (Provides a clear status update on the project's overall completion)
- "I'm planning like alongside the release of return to your silent I'll probably launch like a Kickstarter for my own game and then transition to working on that..." (Indicates future aspirations beyond ROM hacking)

## Potential Interview Topics
- **The Custom Collision System:** Delve into the motivations, challenges, and impact of replacing such a fundamental part of Mario 64. What were the specific issues with the original, and what new possibilities does his system open up?
- **Design Philosophy for a "Sequel" Hack:** Explore how Kaze balances innovation with faithfulness to the original game. How does he decide what to keep, what to change, and what to add when working within the framework of a beloved classic?
- **Collaboration in ROM Hacking:** Discuss the dynamics of working with collaborators like Zeina (animations), and potentially Badub (music) and Biobak (graphics, if they are involved). How are tasks divided and integrated in a distributed, passion-driven project?
- **The Future of Kaze Emanuar:** Expand on his plans for the Kickstarter and his vision for an original 3D platformer. What lessons from ROM hacking will he bring to commercial game development?
- **The Role of the SM64 Decompilation:** How has the decompilation project enabled or changed his approach to creating "Return to Yoshi's Island" compared to older ROM hacking methods?

## Game Development Process
- Currently focused on developing "Course 12," a mine-themed area, which involves significant restructuring and iterative design based on playtesting and Kaze's evaluation of level quality.
- The project is substantially progressed, with Course 12 being "12 out of 15" planned courses.
- Kaze's workflow generally involves establishing level design and geometry first, followed by detailed visual work and polish.
- Key activities include 3D modeling, level layout, implementing gameplay mechanics (e.g., wobbly platforms, planned minecarts), enemy placement, and collectible (Red Coin) distribution.
- Technical aspects include fixing compiler warnings, working with emulators, UV unwrapping, and performance optimization (e.g., Z-sorting geometry, considering array-based collision).

## Personal Insights
- Kaze is highly self-critical of his work, willing to make "big restructures" if he feels a course is "not very good."
- He has a clear vision for his target audience, aiming for "a weird nerd that's been playing Nintendo games in his basement for 25 years," contrasting it with games designed for broader, more casual audiences.
- Kaze holds strong opinions on game design, particularly disliking mechanics that involve waiting (common in some boss fights) and valuing player skill and freedom. He prefers games that offer "new concepts, new ideas."
- He expresses frustration with technical limitations or persistent issues (e.g., a specific compiler warning, emulator quirks) but is determined to fix them.
- He appreciates directness and utility in game mechanics, critiquing games like Portal 2 for being "too meta with the jokes" and a "cannibalization of Portal 1."

## Collaborator Information
- **Badub:** No direct mention of Badub or specific composer collaboration in this transcript. Kaze does ask for "OST wishes," indicating music is a consideration.
- **Biobak:** Mentioned as a graphics artist who will likely do a "reworking" of visual elements, potentially replacing Kaze's placeholder assets (like a fireplace model) with his own, more polished work. This suggests Biobak handles later-stage visual refinement.
    - Quote: "There's also a good chance that during the reworking, Biobank is just gonna remove this and put his own thing."
- **Zeina:** No direct mention of Zeina or specific animation contributions in this transcript. Kaze sarcastically remarks about characters T-posing, but this doesn't detail Zeina's role.
- **Other Contributors:**
    - **Lila (Chat):** Actively provides feedback, suggestions, and code/scripts that Kaze tests. Engages in technical discussions and playful banter. Kaze mentions a bug caused by something Lila wrote.
        - Quote: "The thing you wrote made the bug happen, where if you walk into a ceiling, you just clip into the ground. So I can't use that."
    - **KakiDev (Chat):** Offers technical suggestions, for instance, regarding compiler pragmas and optimizing collision data structures (from linked lists to arrays). Kaze values these ideas.
        - Quote: "yeah your idea sounds sensible khaki honestly maybe there should just be arrays formed when the level boots you know what I'll note that changed on that's a good idea"
    - **Frameperfection:** His patch is used for rounded wall collisions.
        - Quote: "Yes, wall collisions are rounded through frame perfection's patch."

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
- **Major Level Restructure (Course 12):** An area was removed, and a train station element was repositioned to improve flow and introduce new gameplay.
- **New Gameplay Encounters:** A "Boshi" shootout cutscene is planned, involving a Wild West-style duel where the player must press B before Boshi.
- **Level Flow and Navigation:** A key concern is ensuring multiple paths and avoiding dead ends. Kaze actively seeks to improve how players navigate from one part of an area to another (e.g., "I feel like there needs to be a way to go from here to here").
- **Collectibles (Red Coins):** Finding creative and meaningful placements for all eight Red Coins in an area is a recurring design challenge. Red coins in this hack have special B-parameters allowing them to function across different sub-areas. Red coin stars are "bootless" (don't kick Mario out of the level).
- **Technical Challenges:**
    - A persistent compiler warning related to the `fp` register being "bound to multiple values" across different threads is a source of frustration.
    - Emulator compatibility and performance (e.g., Project 64 1.6 crashing, moving to an in-development "Project 64 Legacy").
    - Optimizing performance, such as Z-sorting geometry by naming meshes alphabetically for render order.
- **Visual Design:** Implementing lighting (e.g., using fireplaces as light sources in the mine), UV unwrapping complex geometry, and ensuring assets fit the N64 aesthetic.

## Business Aspects
- No explicit discussion of marketing, funding, or release/distribution plans for "Return to Yoshi's Island" itself.
- Kaze briefly considers the implications of making a public video about an "Ace Bug," weighing the educational benefit against the risk of misuse, which touches on public relations and community management.

## Key Quotes
- "Because I thought about it and I realized the course is not very good. And I think now it is good." (Reflecting his iterative design and commitment to quality)
- "But for like, a weird nerd that's been playing Nintendo games in his basement for 25 years, my game is definitely going to be way better." (Defining his target audience and ambition)
- "We first make the level design and then we make the visuals." (Insight into his development workflow)
- "I fixed all the compiler errors or all the warnings but this one I cannot fix... The issue is that the fp register is bound to multiple values... I don't think I can turn it off." (Highlighting a persistent technical challenge)

## Potential Interview Topics
- **The Iterative Design of Course 12:** Explore the decision-making process behind the "big restructures" in Course 12, including the removal of an area and the introduction of the Boshi shootout. What prompted these changes?
- **Collaborative Dynamics in a Streamed Development:** How does live streaming development impact collaboration with individuals like Lila, KakiDev, and asynchronously with artists like Biobak? How are feedback and contributions integrated?

<extracted_information>
*Extracted on: 20240224*

## Game Development Process
-   **Current Focus: Microcode Optimization:** A significant portion of development is currently dedicated to integrating and optimizing the F3DEX3 microcode, a custom N64 graphics microcode developed by Soren. The goal is to leverage its advanced features and improve performance for "Return to Yoshi's Island" (RTYI).
-   **Iterative Testing and Debugging:** The stream showcases an active debugging session involving Kaze and Soren, comparing performance metrics between F3DEX2, an older version of F3DEX3, and the latest F3DEX3 to diagnose why the new microcode is slower in RTYI. This involves commenting out code sections, analyzing performance counters (RSP/RDP time, FIFO waits), and live troubleshooting.
-   **Level Design Progress:** Level design is well underway. Kaze mentions working on a Mario Kart 64 themed "retro pipe" area, stating it's "course 12 out of 15," indicating substantial progress in level creation.
-   **Technical Integration Challenges:** Integrating F3DEX3 has introduced specific tasks, such as needing to update the game's lighting GBI (graphics binary interface) because "Mario has no colors right now is that we changed the GBI in FBDX3."

## Personal Insights
-   **Pragmatism in Tooling:** Kaze expresses a preference for familiar and reliable tools, even if older, stating about Project64 1.6, "It's just so convenient to use. Parallel still doesn't work for me. I just can't use it."
-   **Focus on Core Game Creation:** Kaze's primary desire is to develop the game itself, rather than get bogged down in emulator or peripheral tool development: "I don't want to lose everything. No, I do not want to make my own emulator. I just want to make my N64 game. Ideally, I wouldn't have to deal with emulators at all."
-   **Awareness of Community and Online Presence:** Kaze is aware of his audience and the demands of streaming, mentioning at the end, "I got to check all the fires of people complaining about the video."
-   **Openness to Experimentation:** Kaze is willing to engage in deep technical dives and experimentation live on stream to solve problems, as seen with the F3DEX3 debugging.

## Collaborator Information
-   **Soren (F3DEX3 Developer):**
    -   The primary collaborator featured in this transcript. Soren is the creator of the F3DEX3 microcode that Kaze is implementing in RTYI.
    -   He joined the stream to help Kaze diagnose performance issues with F3DEX3, explaining its architecture and guiding Kaze through debugging steps.
    -   Soren also created "Sec64," a tool Kaze uses for N64 music sequence formatting.
    -   He was previously director of "Triforce%," an Ocarina of Time arbitrary code execution project.
-   **Zeina (Animations):**
    -   Mentioned indirectly in the context of a past collaboration challenge: "Someone offered to do the animations in 2021 and they kept saying I'll do it, I'll do it, I'll do it and then they didn't do it. And that's why you don't do call-ups." This highlights a past difficulty in securing animation assets. No current positive contribution from Zeina is detailed in this transcript.
-   **Badub (Composer):** No relevant information found in this transcript.
-   **Biobak (Graphics Artist):** No relevant information found in this transcript.
-   **Other Contributors:**
    -   "Ruski": Mentioned briefly by Soren in the context of a "new boot code" potentially preventing unauthorized reproduction of ROM hacks, not as a direct RTYI contributor.

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
-   **Performance-Oriented Lighting:** Kaze prioritizes performance and emulator compatibility. For RTYI, this means "everything here is vertex colored" for static environments. Dynamic lighting is used for actors ("I use world lighting But it's only for moving actors"), sometimes with multiple directional lights ("some levels have up to like Seven light sources active at the same time"). He explicitly avoids N64 point lights for broader compatibility: "No, absolutely not [using point lights] because I want to make sure and runs fine on emulators."
-   **F3DEX3 Performance Bottleneck:** The central challenge discussed is that the new F3DEX3 microcode, despite its intended benefits, is currently running significantly slower in RTYI than older microcodes. The stream is dedicated to identifying the cause of this discrepancy (e.g., "it is a 20% higher time. So that's a little crazy").
-   **Optimizing for High Vertex Counts:** The game features scenes with high vertex counts (e.g., "a scene that has 6600 vertices"). Optimizing the RSP (Reality Signal Processor) and RDP (Reality Display Processor) pipeline for such scenes is crucial.
-   **Retro-Themed Content:** RTYI includes "retro pipes," such as a level themed after Mario Kart 64's Calamari Desert, which involves recreating assets and a specific feel.
-   **Feature vs. Performance Trade-offs:** Discussion around F3DEX3's features like "occlusion plane" involves weighing their benefits against the potential performance cost per vertex.

## Business Aspects
-   **No Direct RTYI Business Plans:** The transcript does not contain explicit information about marketing strategies, funding models, or release/distribution plans specifically for "Return to Yoshi's Island."
-   **Community Donations:** Kaze acknowledges a donation during the stream ("Thank you for the donation, one of ShyGuy"), indicating some level of community financial support through streaming.
-   **Awareness of ROM Hack Commercialization:** Soren discusses the issue of unauthorized commercialization of ROM hacks, citing his experience with "The Missing Link" being sold as reproduction cartridges: "...somebody is just taking our stuff and selling it... I also saw online stores that had like a hundred thousand sales of like people's romhacks they literally made millions of of that." This reflects an awareness of the broader ecosystem and its challenges.
-   **Media Presence:** Kaze notes Soren's feature on "Gamers Nexus," showing an awareness of media attention within the N64/modding community.

## Key Quotes
-   Kaze Emanuar: "The problem is, f3d-ex3 on my game runs significantly slower. So we need to fix that." (Highlights the central technical challenge being addressed).
-   Soren: "My name is Soren. I am a person making F3DEX3 custom microcode for N64, which Kaza is trying to use in Return to Yoshi's Island." (Introduces a key collaborator and the technology at the heart of the discussion).
-   Kaze Emanuar: "No, absolutely not [using point lights in RTYI] because I want to make sure and runs fine on emulators. So I stick to just my f3dx... everything here is vertex colored." (Explains a core design philosophy driven by performance and compatibility).

## Potential Interview Topics
-   **The Vision for F3DEX3 in RTYI:** Explore Kaze's initial reasons for adopting F3DEX3, the features he hopes to leverage, and how the current performance challenges are impacting his development roadmap and expectations.
-   **Balancing Innovation with N64 Limitations:** Discuss Kaze's approach to pushing the boundaries of what's possible on N64 hardware (e.g., with custom microcode, complex scenes) while maintaining playability and performance, especially concerning emulator compatibility.
-   **Collaboration in ROM Hacking:** Delve into the nature of Kaze's collaboration with technical experts like Soren. How do these partnerships form? What are the dynamics, benefits, and challenges of relying on community-developed tools and expertise?
-   **Design Philosophy for "Return to Yoshi's Island":** Ask Kaze about the overall artistic and gameplay vision for RTYI. How do technical decisions (like the lighting model or microcode choice) support or influence this creative vision? What inspired the "retro pipe" concept?
-   **Navigating the ROM Hacking Ecosystem:** Inquire about Kaze's perspective on the broader ROM hacking community, the ethics of creating and distributing hacks, his views on unauthorized commercialization, and his personal motivations for undertaking such large-scale fan projects.
</extracted_information>

## Game Development Process
-   Current focus is on animating and programming Non-Player Characters (NPCs), specifically Dry Bones, a "Piano Guy," and "Cow Boshy." This includes implementing walk/run cycles, interaction animations (like Dry Bones crumbling when jumped on), and unique behaviors (like a shootout minigame with Cow Boshy).
-   Kaze is working on a "secret" collaboration level with a creator named Aza, which is intended for both "Return to Yoshi's Island" and a separate competition (likely the SM64DS Hacking Competition - SEC).
-   There's an ongoing effort to address performance issues, attributed to "program pooling," which seems to be a known limitation Kaze is working within.
-   Sound design is being implemented for NPCs, including footstep sounds and reaction sounds, with consideration for sound priority and fall-off.
-   Texture optimization is actively being done (e.g., for the Piano Guy model) to save memory.
-   The development process is iterative, with Kaze implementing features, testing them in-game, and making adjustments based on how they feel and look (e.g., Dry Bones walk animation choice, animation speeds).

## Personal Insights
-   Kaze strongly values "intrinsic motivation" in game design, preferring gameplay that is inherently fun and engaging over systems that rely on external rewards. He contrasts games like Tears of the Kingdom (high intrinsic motivation) with Pokémon (feeling more like a "job" due to extrinsic motivation).
-   He believes Super Mario 64 is "special" due to its unique physics and movement, which no subsequent game has replicated, making it a prime candidate for ROM hacking.
-   Kaze has a direct and often critical communication style, expressing strong opinions on various topics, including streaming culture (dislike for "farming parasocials") and what he perceives as narcissistic behavior.
-   He shows a pragmatic approach to development, acknowledging limitations (like performance) and working within them or finding practical solutions.
-   He often thinks aloud, explaining his design choices and technical reasoning to his audience during the stream.

## Collaborator Information
-   **Badub:** No relevant information found in this transcript regarding Badub's involvement.
-   **Biobak:**
    -   Kaze shares previews of unreleased content with Biobank via DMs (e.g., the secret collab level).
    -   Kaze asks Biobank for a technical shortcut/hotkey related to his development tools, suggesting Biobank has technical knowledge Kaze respects.
    -   It's implied Biobank is a trusted member of Kaze's inner circle for feedback, though specific contributions to RTYI assets are not detailed in this transcript.
-   **Zeina (Zayna):**
    -   Zayna is a key collaborator providing animations for multiple NPCs, including the Dry Bones, the "Piano Guy," and "Cow Boshy."
    -   Kaze directly praises Zayna's animation work ("Zayna, the Dry Bones look really, really good in-game. You will love them.").
    -   Kaze processes models and textures provided by Zayna, sometimes making adjustments for optimization or engine compatibility (e.g., simplifying Piano Guy's textures, fixing UVs).
-   **Other Contributors:**
    -   **Aza:** Collaborating with Kaze on a level. Both are making a level for a "call up" (collaboration) that will also feature in the "SEC" (likely SM64DS Hacking Competition).
    -   **Sauron:** Mentioned as someone Kaze might collaborate with to debug an issue with "fpdx" in the future.
    -   **Cargo:** Creator of the "Summer Cart" (an N64 flashcart for development), which Kaze discusses and intends to purchase. Not a direct RTYI contributor, but relevant to Kaze's development toolkit.

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
-   **NPC Behavior and Animation:**
    -   Choosing between different walk animations for Dry Bones (settling on a "zombie walk" that fits the character).
    -   Scaling animation speeds with NPC walking speeds for a more natural look.
    -   Designing the Dry Bones to crumble when jumped on, similar to its behavior in official Mario games.
    -   Developing a shootout minigame with Cow Boshy, including a countdown, reaction-based shooting, and dialogue.
    -   Making the Cow Boshy duel progressively easier if the player loses, to ensure accessibility.
-   **Level Design and Aesthetics:**
    -   Discussion of a "retro stage" (Amara Desert 64 from Mario Kart 64) and justifying its "ugly" aesthetic as fitting for a retro-themed area.
    -   Optimizing textures for NPCs like the Piano Guy to save memory and fit N64 limitations.
-   **Technical Challenges:**
    -   Persistent performance issues ("program pooling") that affect frame rate. Kaze acknowledges this as a general problem.
    -   Fixing issues with new fast Piranha DirectX (fpdx) being too slow, requiring future debugging.
    -   Ensuring correct sound implementation, including managing sound priorities to prevent sounds from cutting each other out (e.g., barrel sounds muting other noises).
    -   Debugging NPC interaction logic, such as characters not initiating dialogue correctly.
-   **Dialogue and Story:**
    -   Writing "cowboy-themed" dialogue for Cow Boshy, aiming for an "arrogant, angsty, edgy" persona.
    -   Considering player dialogue choices (e.g., "Yeah partner" vs. "Nary a bit") for interactions.

## Business Aspects
-   **Exposure over Monetization:** Kaze mentions a "double cash in" strategy for the collab level with Aza, referring to gaining exposure by featuring the level in both "Return to Yoshi's Island" and the SEC competition, rather than direct financial gain.
-   **Consideration for Future Projects:** When discussing a hypothetical Wind Waker modding project, Kaze notes it would "not [be] financially worth it unless someone pays me to work on that," indicating an awareness of effort vs. financial return for large, new undertakings, though this doesn't directly apply to RTYI.
-   **No direct discussion of marketing, funding, or specific release/distribution plans for "Return to Yoshi's Island" was found in this transcript.**

## Key Quotes

-   "playing Pokemon kind of feels like a job because you kind of just get the extrinsic motivation whereas if you play a game like um Tears of the Kingdom... that's pure intrinsic motivation." (Highlighting his game design philosophy)
-   "Zayna, the Dry Bones look really, really good in-game. You will love them." (Showcasing collaboration and appreciation for a contributor's work)
-   "you know what causes the game to have so many performance issues yeah it's just program pooling it is what it is." (Acknowledging a significant technical challenge)

*Extracted on: 20240309*

## Game Development Process
- The game "Return to Yoshi's Island" is significantly into development, with Kaze working on "Course 12 out of 15," a Wild West Saloon level.
- Current tasks involve importing and programming new characters and their interactions, such as a "piano playing guy" (a Shy Guy).
- A major recurring challenge is hitting the N64's RAM limits, requiring ongoing optimization of assets like collision maps and 3D models.
- The development process includes integrating assets from collaborators, coding complex behaviors, debugging, performance optimization, and refining gameplay based on iterative testing.
- Kaze is working on a custom, highly optimized engine built upon the Mario 64 decompilation, aiming for high performance (close to 60 FPS on real hardware for some scenes).
- He is using Fast3DX2 for rendering, with a goal to eventually use Fast3DX3.

## Personal Insights
- Kaze considers ROM hacking a "hobby" but dedicates full-time effort to it, alongside his professional career as a programmer on Unreal Engine 5 games.
- He recently had a realization about the importance of "soft skills" (interpersonal communication) and how it changes his perspective on his work.
- Kaze has a highly analytical approach to games, which sometimes leads him to see them as "math formulas," particularly competitive games.
- He expresses a strong desire to create "cool" and "funny" experiences for players, often injecting humor into game mechanics and dialogue.
- His artistic choices can be influenced by personal associations; for instance, he dislikes certain music if it reminds him of negative past experiences (e.g., specific Toad songs).

## Collaborator Information
- Badub: No relevant information found in this transcript regarding contributions to "Return to Yoshi's Island."
- Biobak: No relevant information found in this transcript regarding contributions to "Return to Yoshi's Island."
- Zeina:
    - Provided the 3D model and animations for the "piano playing guy" (Shy Guy) and his piano for the Wild West Saloon level.
    - Kaze integrates Zeyna's assets and sometimes fixes or adjusts them. He shows Zeyna the progress during the stream.
- Other Contributors:
    - **QED:** Kaze mentions planning to ask QED if they can help rip a "card gun" model from Mario Party 2 for use in the game.

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
- **Key Design Choices:**
    - Implementing a "piano playing guy" in a Wild West Saloon who stops playing and interacts with Mario, with the entire bar of NPCs turning to look at Mario if he interrupts.
    - Using directional audio to make the piano music sound like it's coming from the character's location.
    - Planning a "high noon" style duel sequence where Mario uses a "card gun," complete with a 3D modeled countdown.
    - Designing NPC dialogue to fit the Wild West theme (e.g., "translate this into cowboy").
    - Adding Yoshi coins as collectibles, with one planned for "listening to the piano."
- **Obstacles Faced & Solutions:**
    - **RAM Overflow:** A critical and recurring issue. Solutions involve optimizing collision meshes (e.g., reducing triangle count), potentially creating custom collision maps, and being mindful of asset sizes.
    - **Bugs & Glitches:** Debugging various issues, including animation playback problems (e.g., a zero pointer error when checking animation end, animations not looping), crashes due to incorrect object setup (e.g., duplicate geo layouts, exporting temporary objects), and character rotation issues.
    - **NPC Behavior:** Implementing logic for NPCs to react to player actions, such as turning their heads when the piano music stops.
    - **Camera Control:** Setting up specific camera angles and behaviors for cutscenes or special sequences, like the "high noon" duel.
    - **Asset Integration:** Ensuring models and animations from collaborators work correctly within the game engine.

## Business Aspects
- No direct mentions of marketing, funding, or commercial release plans for "Return to Yoshi's Island," as it is a ROM hack.
- Kaze expresses concern about potential leaks of the ROM, indicating a desire to control its distribution and protect the work until he deems it ready for a wider audience or testers. He is selective about who he sends development builds to.
- He distinguishes his ROM hacking work (a "hobby") from his full-time job as a programmer for a game company working on Unreal Engine 5 titles, for which he is under an NDA.

## Key Quotes
- "So our mission today is to import the piano playing guy. Which Zeyna has animated and modeled and he's given him a piano too." (Illustrates collaboration and specific development task)
- "it is a ram overflow we're out of memory cool cool all right we have to optimize the fucking level damn didn't think it would happen so soon well actually the level is almost done so it makes sense that we're getting to the end of our ram" (Highlights a major technical challenge and progress)
- "When the piano guy stops the music, the entire bar should look at you. Yeah, exactly. They'd be like, what the fuck, bro? Why'd you stop my jam? I was vibing." (Shows creative game design idea for player interaction and NPC reactivity)
- "romhacks are technically just a hobby but I do work on them full-time so make of that what you will." (Kaze's dedication to the project)

## Potential Interview Topics
- The creative vision and thematic choices for "Return to Yoshi's Island," particularly the blend of Mario elements with diverse settings like the Wild West.
- The technical deep dive into overcoming N64 limitations: specific optimization strategies for memory and performance that were crucial for this ambitious ROM hack.
- The collaborative workflow in the ROM hacking scene: how Kaze coordinates with artists like Zeyna and others to bring shared visions to life.
- The design philosophy behind interactive NPC encounters, such as the "piano man" scene, and the balance between programmed behavior and emergent fun.
- Kaze's perspective on the evolution of ROM hacking, the tools (like the decompilation project), and the community, and how it impacts projects of this scale.

*Extracted on: 20240316*

## Game Development Process
- **Current Focus:** The stream heavily focuses on the visual refinement and technical implementation of a desert-themed level, specifically addressing quicksand appearance, skybox design, background elements (cliffs), and fog effects. This indicates a stage of detailed level construction and aesthetic polishing.
- **Iterative Approach:** Kaze demonstrates a highly iterative development style, constantly trying different textures, shaders (combiners), and geometric arrangements, then immediately testing and evaluating the results. He states, "Yeah, these are the kind of things where you just have to try, see what happens, see how it turns out, I find."
- **Performance Optimization:** A significant portion is dedicated to N64 performance, discussing render distance, overdraw, polygon counts, and potential benefits from F3DX3 (a custom microcode) and culling. He mentions aiming for solid frame rates even with complex visuals: "30. And we didn't even optimize or put FADX3 in yet. Oh, that's crazy." He later discovers culling wasn't even enabled, implying significant performance gains are still possible.
- **Tooling:** Kaze mentions using tools like Fast64 (a Mario 64 level editor) and Blender, and encountering/working around their limitations or bugs (e.g., "Fast64 rendering bug," "fast64 resetting my hex edits").
- **Hardware Testing:** He performs tests on actual N64 hardware ("Let's check this out on N64 and see how it performs") to get accurate performance metrics beyond emulation.

## Personal Insights
- **Artistic Vision & Frustration:** Kaze has a strong vision for the game's aesthetics and "vibe," particularly concerning the fog color ("The fog color right now is very essential for the art style here. Making it all yellow would change the vibe a lot."). He expresses frustration when technical hurdles or tool limitations impede this vision (e.g., "Dude, I gotta get rid of this cliff in the skybox, it is pissing me off," "This combiner is unworkable").
- **Problem-Solving Attitude:** Despite frustrations, he displays a persistent problem-solving approach, exploring various technical solutions for visual challenges, often thinking aloud and engaging with chat for ideas.
- **Humor and Candor:** Kaze is candid about his process, mistakes, and opinions, often using humor (e.g., "What an animation, I call the animation comedy death," "Surely sand 6 will be better than sand 21, clueless"). He also briefly rants about YouTube recommendations, showing a more personal side.
- **Pride in Optimization:** He shows pride in pushing the N64's capabilities, especially regarding his project's optimization compared to others ("How the fuck did LRT not even reach solid 30 FPS? Because they ain't me."). He also brags about Sauron's assessment of RTYI's optimization.

## Collaborator Information
- **Badub (presumed "my dupe"):**
    - Contribution: Composer for the game. Kaze states, "...my dupe wants to make all of it," referring to the music.
    - Interaction: Kaze hopes to release an OST cartridge alongside the game, implying a significant and valued contribution from the composer.
- **Biobak:**
    - Contribution: Graphics artist. Kaze mentions, "He wanted to help me rework a bunch of levels."
    - Interaction/Status: Kaze expresses concern: "Dude, has anyone seen Biobank recently? He's been gone for a while... I hope he's not gone. That'd be really unfortunate for the case empire." This suggests Biobak is a valued contributor whose absence is felt.
- **Zeina:**
    - No relevant information found in this transcript regarding Zeina or animations. The "comedy death" animation mentioned at the start seems to be Kaze's own experiment or a placeholder.
- **Other Contributors:**
    - **Sauron:** Working on F3DX3 (a custom N64 microcode) optimization. Kaze states Sauron "thinks that in Return to Yoshi's Island the memory and RDP is so optimized that with F3dx3 the RSP becomes the bottleneck. And because F3dx3 has more RSP costs, that is likely it. So he's making a version of F3dx3 that has some optimized RDSP." This collaboration is key for performance.
    - **Eric:** Kaze asks, "Does Eric hack quicksand right now?" This sounds like another ROM hacker whose work Kaze might be following or referencing, rather than a direct collaborator on RTYI from this specific transcript.
    - **Chat (Clayman, Cack Honka Honka, g-boy, Rainy, Liliana, Jan, Agirov, Seymour Sam, etc.):** While not formal collaborators, the chat actively provides suggestions and feedback that Kaze sometimes considers or responds to (e.g., "Can't you render the distance cliffs in another layer like OOT renders in Skybox? Yes, that's what I would do.").

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
- **Skybox and Background Aesthetics:** A major challenge is creating a convincing and aesthetically pleasing skybox/background that integrates with the level, manages render distance, and avoids looking "floaty." Kaze experiments with distant cliffs, fog, color matching, and parallax effects.
    - *Challenge:* "One thing I worry about is that players might think they have to go to the bottom here. I'd like to prevent that a lot."
    - *Solution Attempt:* Fading distant elements into fog or a background color, using multiple layers for cliffs.
- **Quicksand Visuals:** Finding a good visual representation for quicksand that looks appealing and functional.
    - *Challenge:* Initial attempts look "terrible." "Quicksand is not it, definitely not."
    - *Solution Attempt:* Experimenting with textures, shaders (combiners), fading edges, and ensuring it's visually distinct from walkable ground.
- **Performance vs. Visual Fidelity:** Constantly balancing the desire for complex, appealing visuals with the N64's hardware limitations.
    - *Challenge:* "The problem is, this texture is so big that it is not possible to make it slowly move, at least not cheaply."
    - *Decision:* Opting for solutions that are "cheap to render," simplifying geometry, and relying on upcoming F3DX3 optimizations.
- **Art Style Consistency:** Maintaining a cohesive art style, especially regarding colors (e.g., the importance of the blue fog, reluctance to change it).
    - *Challenge:* "The fog color right now is very essential for the art style here... Making it all yellow would change the vibe a lot."
- **Level Element: Train:** Integrating a moving train element, including fixing its rotation and pitch to match the surface.

## Business Aspects
- **Potential for an N64 Game in 2024:** Kaze mentions, "So, yeah, so fun fact, there was a company that approached me recently and they said they want to make an N64 game in 2024. Looks like they might be doing it, but we'll find out in June." He discusses the marketing potential: "...if you have the marketing of, hey, this is an N64 game, but there's also a PC port available, it's kind of insane. That would make the news and you would get so much marketing for free."
- **OST Release:** "I'm hoping that I can release RTYI alongside an OST cartridge." This indicates a plan for a physical or distributable product related to the game.
- **Marketing Awareness (General):** While RTYI is a ROM hack, Kaze shows an understanding of game marketing principles when discussing the potential N64 company project.

## Key Quotes
- "Yeah, these are the kind of things where you just have to try, see what happens, see how it turns out, I find." (Illustrates his iterative development philosophy).
- "The fog color right now is very essential for the art style here. Making it all yellow would change the vibe a lot." (Highlights the importance of artistic vision and consistency).
- "He said he thinks that in Return to Yoshi's Island the memory and RDP is so optimized that with F3dx3 the RSP becomes the bottleneck... So he's making a version of F3dx3 that has some optimized RDSP." (Shows collaborative effort in pushing technical boundaries and pride in optimization).
- "Dude, this actually looks incredible for N64." (Kaze's own assessment of the visual progress on actual hardware).

## Potential Interview Topics
1.  **The Balancing Act:** Explore Kaze's process of balancing his ambitious artistic vision for "Return to Yoshi's Island" with the strict technical limitations of the N64 hardware. How does he decide which compromises to make?
2.  **Collaboration in ROM Hacking:** Discuss the nature of his collaborations (e.g., with Sauron on F3DX3, Biobak on graphics, "my dupe" on music). How do these partnerships form and function in the ROM hacking community?
3.  **The "N64 Revival" Idea:** Delve deeper into his thoughts on the company aiming to make a new N64 game in 2024. What does he see as the appeal and challenges of such a venture, and would he be involved?
4.  **Iterative Design and Community Feedback:** Kaze often experiments live and responds to chat. How integral is this iterative process and real-time community feedback to shaping the final game?
5.  **From Passion Project to Potential Product:** Discuss the idea of an OST cartridge. Does he envision other ways for ROM hacking projects like RTYI to have a life or tangible presence beyond digital distribution?

*Extracted on: 20240323*

## Game Development Process
- The game "Return to Yoshi's Island" is in its later stages, with Kaze stating, "only three levels are missing and i already finished one area of that that's like end game."
- Significant off-stream work has been done on secret areas and engine polishing.
- A major focus is ensuring the game runs on actual N64 hardware, with recent success in getting parts of the game to run at "40 FPS before we even optimized it," though some areas like the "overworld is fucked" and crashes occur.
- Kaze is also working on a smaller, "secret project" referred to as a "ROM-Mech" using the same engine.
- Current stream focus is on programming "Boshi, the dino with the gun," including a duel minigame.

## Personal Insights
- Kaze is highly passionate about his work, expressing excitement: "Dude, I wish I could show you guys what I made upstream. It's so cool."
- He takes pride in his custom engine: "Well, basically everything I'm going to release is going to use my engine."
- He has a pragmatic approach to development, willing to simplify features if they become too complex to implement effectively (e.g., the duel countdown).
- Kaze is aware of and somewhat resigned to the possibility of Nintendo takedowns, based on past experiences: "A lot of people tell me that they're worried that this game is going to get taken down by nintendo but i never understood what they think that would look like..."
- He values open source principles for software like Blender: "And it is open source, which means it's actually going to be good in 5 years."

## Collaborator Information
- Badub: [No specific new information about Badub's contributions during this stream segment, though listed as a known composer for the project.]
- Biobak: A graphics artist who reviews and improves Kaze's models: "usually after I'm done, we got Biobank looking over it and he makes them a lot better."
- Zeina: Implied to work on animations. Kaze mentions, "Can you believe Zeyna's on babysitting instead of making games with me right now?"
- Other Contributors:
    - **Leela:** Collaborating on the "secret project" (ROM-Mech). Working on implementing Quaternions into the engine, which will allow for "free translation" in animations. Described as "another RobMaker" Kaze is collaborating with.
    - **UED:** Provided the 3D model for the cork gun used in the Boshi duel: "Good thing UED has sent me a model of it."
    - **CX-Linx:** A community member Kaze interacts with during technical discussions.
    - **Unnamed individual:** Emailed Kaze a "new sine and cosine approximation that might actually be worth it."

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
- **Boshi Duel Minigame:**
    - Designing a quick-draw duel mechanic: "3, 2, 1 and then there's a random delay and it says go. And you gotta press B to shoot him."
    - Penalty for shooting early: "If you shoot early your gun will blow up in your face."
    - Iterating on the countdown presentation: Initially considered a HUD countdown, but shifted to a full cutscene due to programming complexity: "Wait, a HUD countdown is gonna suck to program... we'll just make a cutscene fuck it this is painful to do without a cutscene."
    - Balancing reaction time: "first attempt is really difficult i'm thinking like 280 millisecond reaction time and then every time you lose you get like three frames more reaction time." This also needs to account for modern display lag.
    - Camera work for the cutscene: Involves significant trial and error to get framing right for both widescreen and 4:3 aspect ratios.
- **Performance and N64 Hardware:**
    - Constant effort to optimize for N64 hardware, including fixing crashes (e.g., "the overworld is fucked").
    - Implementing culling techniques: "You see these beams here? We can make it so that they cull... We can just make it not process the triangles at all."
    - Addressing RAM limitations, e.g., by decimating models like the egg.
- **Animation System Limitations:** Mario 64's animation system doesn't inherently support translation for animated objects beyond the first frame, requiring workarounds.
- **"Save State Yoshi" Raps:** A unique, if controversial, feature where a Yoshi character raps at the player for using save states. Kaze defends the creative choice despite some chat members finding them "cringe."

## Business Aspects
- **Future Projects & Funding:** Kaze plans to launch a Kickstarter for an original game after "Return to Yoshi's Island": "i'm gonna bundle it together with the ad for my kickstarter for the game i'm gonna make after i'm done with return to yoshi's islands."
- **Monetization Stance:** He is against making Patreon-exclusive content for this ROM hack: "I'm not making any Patreon exclusives. I don't want people to even think I'm trying to bait people into my Patreon."
- **Release Strategy Concerns:** Worried about timing the ROM hack's release to avoid coinciding with major Nintendo game releases, which he believes increases the likelihood of a takedown: "if you release your romhack around the same time as a big nintendo game comes out you are going to get taken down 100% like right away."
- **Copyright & Takedowns:** Has experienced numerous video takedowns by Nintendo previously (affecting "70 of my videos," including Blender tutorials and Net64 showcases) and anticipates potential takedown of the game's trailer, planning a "copyright free version."

## Key Quotes
- "Do you guys actually realize how crazy it is how close we're done to being done like only three levels are missing and i already finished one area of that that's like end game but it's still gonna take a long time but still it's like it's the last fifth of the game that feels like end stretch to me." (Reflecting on project progress)
- "Well, basically everything I'm going to release is going to use my engine." (On the versatility and importance of his custom engine)
- "A lot of people tell me that they're worried that this game is going to get taken down by nintendo but i never understood what they think that would look like... they already did that [takedowns on videos]." (On the ever-present Nintendo concern)

## Potential Interview Topics
- **The Vision for "Return to Yoshi's Island":** Beyond being a ROM hack, what is the overarching creative vision and desired player experience for this game? What personal significance does this project hold?
- **Collaborative Dynamics:** Explore the nature of Kaze's collaborations (with Biobak, Leela, Zeina, UED, etc.). How are these partnerships formed and maintained, especially in a remote, fan-driven project environment?
- **Navigating the "Nintendo Risk":** A deeper discussion on how the threat of Nintendo takedowns influences Kaze's development choices, release strategies, and his general philosophy on creating fan works.
- **Engine Development and Technical Innovation:** Delve into the journey of creating and refining his custom Mario 64 engine. What were the primary motivations, major technical achievements, and how does it empower his creative ambitions for both ROM hacks and future original projects?
- **The "Boshi Duel" as a Case Study:** Use the development of the Boshi duel minigame (from concept to near-completion in the stream) to illustrate Kaze's iterative design process, problem-solving approach, and how he balances technical feasibility with creative goals.

*Extracted on: 20240330*

## Game Development Process
-   The stream focuses on developing features for a Western-themed level, "Rent Center Badland," including swinging saloon doors, a "Boshy" dueling character, and a bartender Koopa whose hat grows.
-   A to-do list for the current level includes fixing floating train tracks, making train wheels move, adding sound/smoke/VFX to the train, and implementing a chain chomp.
-   Memory management is a consideration, with plans to move Wiggler and Chain Chomp memory allocation to an object-specific bank.
-   Kaze mentions a "whole ROM egg" (likely a significant portion or level of the game) has been completed that a community member (Lila) hasn't seen yet.
-   The development is iterative, with features being built, tested, debugged, and refined based on Kaze's vision and community feedback (e.g., Boshy duel timing, saloon door mechanics).
-   There's an ongoing effort to optimize for N64 hardware, with collaborators like Sauron working on reducing RSP (Reality Signal Processor) load.
-   The team is working on finalizing star names for levels.

## Personal Insights
-   Kaze values objective and unemotional criticism, stating, "Leaving a comment, critiquing whatever I made is always good... there's also a good chance that I'll seriously look at it and reconsider my decisions."
-   He has a strong opinion against self-inserts in games: "I don't put myself in my games I Think self inserts is a little cringe."
-   Kaze reflects on the ROM hacking community and its perception of other hacks (e.g., Star Revenge), preferring to let others enjoy what they like while maintaining his own standards and perspective.
-   He emphasizes making features efficient: "Every time you program something, you want it to be free of cost. If you're not using that part of codes."
-   He expresses a desire for his game to be polished and for mechanics to "feel good" (e.g., "speed kicks in this game feel so good").

## Collaborator Information
-   **Badub (composer):** No specific information about Badub's contributions or interactions was found in this transcript.
-   **Biobak (graphics artist):**
    -   Significantly reworking graphics for levels, such as Course 11, making them look "insane" and adding depth using "combiners" (likely a Fast64 feature). Kaze: "It's crazy. Looks so much better already."
    -   Communicates with Kaze about technical issues (e.g., "Biobank had an issue with the combiner, so he sent me an image").
-   **Zeina (animations):** No specific information about Zeina's contributions or interactions was found in this transcript. (The transcript mentions Zeno for textures, which might be a different person or a typo for Zeina, but context points to textures.)
-   **Other Contributors:**
    -   **Zeno:** Making textures for the "Rent Center Badland" level. ("Zeno's making the textures.")
    -   **Sauron:** Working on optimizing F3DX (N64 graphics microcode) to be less RSP-intensive, aiming to improve performance for "Return to Yoshi's Island." ("He's currently working on making F3DX less RSP intensive in the hopes that it'll work on RTYI.")
    -   **Lila (community member/tester):** Provides significant feedback on gameplay elements like duel timing and visual design (saloon doors). Kaze actively discusses and sometimes implements her suggestions.
    -   **B-Turk (community member):** Actively contributed to writing and refining the rap lyrics for the "Space Yoshi" anti-save-state feature during the stream.
    -   **Aza (Eiza):** Kaze mentions wanting permission to show a "compact" they made and refers to a "short hack" he created with Eiza.
    -   **Dan (community member):** Hosts a voice channel where Kaze and others discuss technical aspects of N64 development like shadows and graph nodes.
    -   **Red (audio):** Mentioned as working on audio, though Kaze jests about the pace of their work. ("Have you ever seen Red finish anything ever? Come on.")

## Game Design Decisions/Challenges
-   **Saloon Doors:** Significant time spent designing and debugging the physics and interaction of swinging saloon doors, including rotation logic, player collision, and visual appearance (size, texture). A key challenge was getting the doors to rotate correctly based on Mario's approach and interaction, eventually solved by using "angle to Mario" instead of "face angle."
-   **Boshy Duel Mechanic:** Iterative refinement of a dueling character ("Boshy"), including the timing of shots, adding a visual countdown (3-2-1), adjusting sound effects, and implementing pitch changes for Boshy's voice. Feedback from Lila influenced the duel's timing.
-   **Bartender Koopa's Hat:** Designing a visual gag where the bartender's hat grows larger with each star collected in the level. This involved adjusting the 3D model vertices.
-   **Sound Design:** Implementing a system to pitch individual sound effects and character voices, particularly for Boshy and dialogue boxes, to enhance characterization and game events. Kaze aimed for an efficient implementation.
-   **Memory and Performance:** Ongoing consideration for N64 limitations, such as moving certain objects to specific memory banks to free up resources and relying on collaborators (Sauron) to optimize graphics performance.
-   **Fast64 Tool Issues:** Encountering and working around bugs or quirks in the Fast64 development tool, such as "render mode bleeding."
-   **Anti-Save-State Feature ("Space Yoshi"):** Designing a humorous in-game consequence for using save states, involving a "Space Yoshi" character delivering rap lyrics. The lyrics themselves were a collaborative effort with the community (B-Turk).
-   **Yoshi Coins:** Acknowledged as an incomplete element for the current stage that needs finishing.
-   **Minigames:** Hesitancy to add a full new minigame (like horseshoe throwing) due to memory constraints in the current level: "We kind of have an issue with this level in that we're kind of out of memory."

## Business Aspects
-   **Content Creation for Audience Engagement:** Kaze mentions paying a "shorts guy" approximately $270 per year to create YouTube Shorts from his stream content. He also considers clipping stream highlights for Shorts himself ("Can I just clip all this shit and make it into YouTube shorts?").
-   **No Direct Monetization or Formal Release Plans Mentioned:** As a ROM hack, there's no discussion of selling the game. While eventual release is implied, no specific timelines or distribution strategies are detailed in this transcript. Kaze mentions one "ROM egg" is finished but "we didn't even release it yet."

## Key Quotes
-   "Leaving a comment, critiquing whatever I made is always good... But there's also a good chance that I'll seriously look at it and reconsider my decisions. I feel like that's kind of like an integrity thing you should do." (Kaze on handling criticism)
-   "It was all because I used fucking face angle instead of angle to Mario. I think it was. Whoops." (Kaze on solving a frustrating bug with the saloon doors, highlighting the trial-and-error nature of development)
-   "Biobank had an issue with the combiner, so he sent me an image and he made it look like this. It's crazy. Looks so much better already. It looks like it has so much depth." (Kaze expressing excitement about a collaborator's graphical improvements)

## Potential Interview Topics
